story: Binge eater spends £, on dream body after living a letime on fad dietsAmy Elsley, , from Rainham, East London, used to keep eating until she felt sick but now after big changes to her le she says she is a better mum and her le is betterA large part of Amy Elsleys stomach was removed ten months ago - and the surgery totally transformed her le Image: amys.sleeved.le   MERCURY PRESSByLucy NotarantonioSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Mar |comments A binge eater who spent £,k to get her le back on track says she is now a better mum after spending a letime on fad diets . Amy Elsley, , began dieting aged  but struggled to maintain a healthy weight.She says it caused her to become severely depressed as she turned to food for comfort. The scenic artist weighed st lbs at her heaviest - and decided she had to do something about it. The mum-of-one from Rainham, East London, found it hard to stop eating once she started, until she decided to undergo surgery in May . A large part of Amyaposs stomach was removed for £, last year and she says its the best decision she has ever made.Now, ten months on, Amy is st lbs and couldnapost be happier. She said: I have always been a yo-yo dieter but it didnapost matter how much I lost as I would always put double back on. Eventually, I grew sick and tired of my reflection. I was ashamed and disgusted that I had let myself get to the weight I was at.I knew I needed an extra bit of help which is why I opted for a gastric sleeve. Amy used to eat large portions and McDonaldaposs frequently for her lunch. She recalls skipping meals such as breakfast and to compensate binged during the evening.But at the start of , Amy was signed off work with depression. She adds: I would never eat breakfast but once I started to eat, I could never stop. It was like I wouldnapost give myself chance to feel full. Iaposd just keep on eating until I felt like I was going to be sick. Iaposd typically order nine chicken nuggets, a double cheese burger, large fries and cheese melts from McDonaldaposs for my lunch. Then Iaposd always have a huge portion of stodgy dinner. My weight and appearance combined with the lockdown made me feel so depressed. I wasnapost showering for days nor leaving my bed as I had hit a really low point in my le. I wasnapost able to be the mum my daughter Evie, five, deserves which is what prompted me to make the call to Spire London East Hospital.  Within two months, I was on the table ready for the surgery. Amy used her le savings to fund the surgery - and now insists it was worth every penny as she feels like a new woman. She adds: I havenapost got one regret. I finally have my le back. When I was overweight, I was a recluse and I couldnapost wear the clothes I like. I wouldnapost even put makeup on as I didnapost want to draw any kind of attention to myself. Itaposs so hard when you are big to feel accepted as people constantly judge you. But now I am like a completely dferent person. I am a better mum to Evie and the first to go down the slide with her or on a ride. Previously, I was too ashamed and embarrassed in case I got stuck. story: Exclusive: Dog with no nose gets adopted by loving family after being rescued from badger-baitingThree-year-old Patterdale terrier Riddle is learning how to play and cuddle after being adopted by a forever family from Dogs Trust Canterbury and saved from illegal badger-baitingThe little Patterdale terrier has found a warm home and a loving family after being rescued Image: Samantha DantonByNia DaltonSpecialist Writer:,  Mar |comments A dog with a missing nose who was rescued from badger-baiting has been adopted by a loving family, after his hunt for a home was shared on the . The three-year-old Patterdale terrier named Riddle was at Dogs Trust Canterbury, desperately waiting for someone to accept his unique appearance.Staff were in awe of his absolutely lovely personality and well manners - that later went on to win over his adoptive new owners, Samantha and David Danton, and their -year-old daughter, Evie. Rescuers believed the pup was forced to compete in an illegal blood sport due to his injured nose and scars on his legs.Samantha, , based in Clfsend, told The Mirror : He is fabulous and doesnapost have an ounce of aggression. He is so calm and just amazing.  to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. Samantha and her family have been looking for a rescue dog since their miniature schnauzer passed away in March . She fell in love with Riddle when she spotted his little face online. It wasnapost necessarily the fact that he didnapost have a nose, but his poor face kept playing on my mind. He had been through so much, Samantha said. Two weeks ago, Samantha and David, , were invited to meet Riddle for the first time at Dogs Trust, then went again to take him for a walk with their daughter.He was very friendly and as soon as he saw us, he rolled over and let us tickle his tummy. He was incredibly welcoming, Samantha said. On Sunday  March, the family brought him home and changed his name to Ralphie. He was named Riddle after Voldemort because of his missing nose. We wanted to change his name to give him a fresh start in le, Samantha explained. Ralphie had never been inside a house before and found the sofa quite amusing at first. He kept trying to e down the back, Samantha said. We taught him how to play with toys and heaposs learning to bring balls in from the garden. Yesterday I was on my own with him and we had a cuddle. It was quite emotional. Despite his dferences in appearance, Riddle is just like any other dog and can still use his working nostrils. news uk-news five-signs-charles-wants-repair-"Prince Harry offers continued support to those suffering in UkraineByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments One year has passed since Prince Harry and Meghan Markle sat down with Oprah Winfrey for a bombshell chat about their time as working royals. In it, they opened up about many members of the Firm - with Harry accusing his dad Prince Charles of cutting him off financially and not taking his calls. Even after the explosive chat, he appeared on the Armchair Expert podcast, where he lashed out at Charlesaposs parenting and talked about total neglect on the Apple TV series The Me You Canapost See. Later reports claimed that relations between the pair were at rock bottom - but recently there have been signs that Harry, Meghan and Charles could be ready to bury the hatchet. Here we take a look at them... Full of praise  One of the first signs that Harry and Charlesapos relationship could be improving was just a few days into . Charles wrote an essay for Newsweek, where he issued a call for urgent action to save the environment.In the piece, he praised both Prince William and Harry for their work in raising awareness of the issue. He spoke about how he was proud of both of his sons for having recognised the threat of climate change. He said: Most recently, my elder son, William, launched the prestigious Earthshot Prize to incentivise change and help repair our planet over the next ten years by identying and investing in the technologies that can make a dference. And my younger son, Harry, has passionately highlighted the impact of climate change, especially in relation to Africa, and committed his charity to being net-zero. Shortly after the Newsweek essay was released, the Mirror revealed that Charles had held several “good-natured and enjoyable” video calls with Harry. Sources close to Charles said that despite reports of the two not speaking, Charles and Harry have been on “a journey of rediscovery” in terms of their relationship. One said: “The Prince of Wales has spoken to his son frequently in recent months. He loves him very much, as he does both his children, and he looks forward to them being able to spend time together in the near future.” Regular contact And it seems these video calls might not be a one-off for Harry and Charles and itaposs been suggested they talk regularly.Thataposs because, writing in the , royal expert Camilla Tominey claims that Prince Charles is thought to be in regular contact with his youngest son.However, she added: Whether Meghan will everto the UK remains to be seen. Olive branch invitation Meanwhile, it has also been reported that Charles offered his son an olive branch by offering him an invitation to stay with him the next time he brings his family to the UK.The offer of bringing the family together for the first time since Harry and Meghan decided to quit their royal roles and set up home in Calornia was made by the heir in the lead up to Christmas, it is understood. But Charles’s good-natured plan, in an attempt to heal the rt between him and his son, has been thrown into doubt after Harry suggested awould come at “too great a personal risk” due to his security situation. Meghanaposs photo Meanwhile, another sign came on Tuesday when eagle-eyed royal fans spotted a touching photo of Meghan Markle that has pride of place in Charles and the Duchess of Cornwallaposs home.Camilla welcomed three female rowers, who crossed the Atlantic in record time, to Clarence House - the London home she shares with Charles - to mark International Womenaposs Day. They were joined by former male rower Tim Christian and were pictured chatting with Camilla in a sitting room at the royal residence.  Behind where the guests were sitting, royal fans noticed a side table that was filled with lovely family photos. And one of them included a stunning black-and-white image of Meghan with Charles on her wedding day in . When Meghan married Harry, Charles escorted the bride halfway down the aisle of St Georgeaposs Chapel in Windsor - and the framed photo appears to depict this. title: how worried should new covid
story: How worried should we be about new Covid spike as cases surge by % in a weekInfections appear to be rising in over s as the BA. Omicron iant spreads, with experts sounding the alarm that the pandemic is not over yet despite Boris Johnsons Living with Covid plan London Overground" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _BRITAIN-TRANSPORT-RAIL-STRIKE.jpg" width"" "" Commuters, some wearing face coverings due to Covid-, exit a Transport for LondonLondon Overground Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Mar |commentsThe Covid pandemic is not over yet and the latest surge in cases is a concern, say experts.Infections appear to be rising in older people as socialising increases in the wake of Freedom Day last month, vaccine immunity wanes and BA. - a more transmissible Omicron strain - spreads.Although BA. is more contagious than BA., clinical data does not suggest a signicant dference in disease severity.Wednesday saw recorded infections rise by more than  percent and deaths by two thirds compared to last week, according to data from the Department of Health. Hospital admissions have also risen sharply, with , people in hospitals with the virus on March  and  requiring a mechanical ventilator.The worrying figures come just weeks before the government plans to scrap free lateral flow tests for most people on April .Are you worried by the rise  Have your say in the comment section Free PCR tests will also not be available to people with symptoms as the government implements its aposLiving with Covidapos plan, introduced on February . Data from a study by Imperial College’s React- team shows around one in  peoplein England were infected between February  and March  - with the virus particularly prevalent in people over . The figure was a drop on the . percent recorded between January  and , but was the second-highest rate since the study started in .  The React- data comes from nearly , swabs from homes across England. It shows infections have dropped since the January peak but scientists involved said the R value, or the average number of infected, remained below  for those  and under. But for those  and over it stood at .. Experts are investigating whether hospitalisation rates are being driven by “unshielding”, where some of the most vulnerable people have ed back to normal after two years of self-isolation. Dr Jenny Harries, chief executive of the UK Health Security Agency , told Sky News: These data confirm that cases have declined substantially following the peak of the Omicron wave.However, the increasing presence of the BA. sub-lineage of Omicron and the recent slight increase in infections in those over  show that the pandemic is not over and that we can expect to see COVID circulating at high levels.  Professor Paul Elliot, director of Imperial College Londonaposs React programme, said: At the moment, weaposre possibly seeing the beginning of an uptick, but we donapost know where itaposs going to go. Mark Woolhouse, professor of infectious disease epidemiology at the University of Edinburgh, said it was “impossible to make a sensible prediction” about the size of any BA. wave but the situation needed close monitoring.He told the: “The worry is that it’s hard to see anything happening in the next few weeks that will reverse the growth of BA. unless, that is, people decide on their own account to step up precautions.”Danny Altmann, professor of immunology at Imperial College, said the recent rise was foreseeable. “We’ll see a great deal more of this, along the lines of recent resurgent spikes in Scotland and Hong Kong,” he said. “Caseloads were by no means low or under control as we came out of all mitigations and, when you add in waning immunity and the enhanced transmissibility of BA., it looks like we are in for a dficult period, especially for the elderly.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSDepartment of HealthGrant ShappsHospitalsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: hundreds russian made items removed
story: Hundreds of Russian-made items are removed from Asda, Sainsburys, Aldi and moreSupermarket chains including Asda, Sainsburys and Aldi have removed Russian-made items from their shelves following the invasion of Ukraine by Vladimir Putins forcesSainsburys is removing Russian-made stock Image: REUTERSByKate LallyTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |comments Major supermarket chains in the UK have removed hundreds of Russian made products from their shelves in protest at the invasion of Ukraine.Asda, Sainsburyaposs, Aldi and Waitrose are among the stores that have taken a stand against Russia, with its actions in Ukraine having been widely condemned around the world. Sanctions have been imposed on a government level while companies have also inidually decided to stop their trade with Russian firms.It is thought that the boycott of Russian goods along with other economic sanctions could force Vladimir Putin into ending the invasion. Many major supermarkets have stopped selling Russian products, with some taking more signicant action than others, reported the Liverpool Echo. Tesco said it will not be removing any products from its shelves, but it will not place any further orders with Russian suppliers.A spokesperson for Tesco reportedly stated that it would no longer be “buying products from businesses that are wholly Russian-owned”. A statement from the supermarket read: “We are supporting humanitarian relief efforts through our partnerships with the Red Cross, food banks and other relief organisations to help those affected in Ukraine and neighbouring countries.” Here are all the products that have been removed from supermarkets: AsdaAsda has confirmed it is removing all products that originate from Russia from its stores and online - around  items in total.Most of these are spirits, though the list also includes fish and some sweets. Asda’s co-owner Mohsin Issa said: “We stand with our customers and colleagues who are shocked by the Russian invasion of Ukraine – and our thoughts are with those people whose lives are affected by this crisis.”On March , Asda and its charity, the Asda Foundation, announced a £m package to support displaced Ukrainian families in Europe and the UK. Aldi The budget-friendly retailer has said it will no longer sell Russian vodka.At the start of the month, Aldi announced that they would be making a donation to the Red Cross Ukraine Crisis Appeal.They said in a statement: We stand together with Aldi colleagues across the world and will be making a donation to the Red Cross Ukraine Crisis Appeal. After initially not confirming the donation amount, the supermarket confirmed they would be donating a further  million euros to established aid organisations to ensure help reaches those that need it most.  SainsburyapossProducts Sainsburyaposs have removed include the Russian Standard vodka and Karpayskiye black sunflower seeds.A Sainsbury’s spokesperson said: “We stand united with the people of Ukraine. We have reviewed our product range and have decided to remove from sale all products that are % sourced from Russia. The supermarket giant has also recently renamed its Chicken Kiev to Kyiv - the Ukrainian capital - to stand with Ukraine. Customers should see the change in packaging over the next few weeks.  Co-op, Morrisons and Waitrose The Co-op, Morrisons and Waitrose have also removed Russian vodka from their shelves. A spokesperson for the Co-op said the decision to remove the sale of Russian-made vodka was a sign of solidarity with the people of Ukraine. A spokesman for Morrisons, meanwhile, said: “We have taken action on our vodka lines today including delisting Russian Standard.” Waitrose and John Lewis said earlier this month they would no longer sell products made in Russia, starting with Russian vodka and one line of pizza oven pellets. title: inside worst hotel guests complain
story: Inside worst hotel where guests complain of filthy rooms with blood-stained duvetOther guests who stayed at The Airport Hotel in Manchester claim their bedding had not been changed for three weeks as the budget hotel is rated two out of five bubbles on TripAdvisorThis hotel in Manchester has left guests horried Image: Manchester Evening News WSByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsGuests at an airport hotel have slammed the filthy rooms after finding what appears to be bloodstains on the bedding. Others who stayed at The Airport Hotel in Manchester claim there was a huge stench of cigarette smoke and alleged their bedding had not been changed for three weeks.The budget hotel has faced complaints from multiple guests online, and some have claimed that they found suspicious stains on a duvet and dirt throughout their bedroom, ManchesterEveningNews reports. The accommodation, which is rated two out of five bubbles on TripAdvisor, is owned by Britannia Hotels - which has recently been voted the worst hotel chain in the UK for the ninth year running.In recent weeks, a series of terrible reviews have been shared on the travel site, and guests at the Northenden hotel branch branded it diabolical and filthy. One guest, named Emma, claimed that she had been staying in the hotel after fleeing domestic abuse. Rating the hotel just one star, she wrote: Cleaning staff haven’t changed my bedding in THREE WEEKS actually think I’m going to be sick from how they’ve treated me. Another, named Laura alleged she had an awful experience where she found herself sinking right through the mattress through to the other side. Laura claimed that after she changed rooms three times she ended up in one with stained bedding. She said: Given room  and wanted a little sleep. Pulled back the duvet and the bed springs were coming through the mattress so we were given another room on the same floor. I sat on the bed and sunk through it! It jolted my back really badly. I took a picture of the mattress to show the manager.  Was given a third room and the manager came with us and again a mattress with the springs sowingthrough. He admitted that all the mattresses in the hotel were in the same sorry state. So I asked for spare duvets to sleep on to try to create padding from springs. One of the spare duvets had blood on it! I then got the spare pillows down and they had hairs all over them from a previous guest. Also there were chocolate buttons under my bed and a chupa cup wrapper under my friendaposs bed. Certainly not cleaned. Putting hygiene sticker on the door make no dferenceyou do not vacuum the floor! She also claims that she woke up in the morning with terrible back pain and was forced to lie on the dirty floor to try and relieve it. Another guest, Catherine B, said it was the worst hotel she has ever stayed in. She said: Our allocated room was an unprepared room that had not been cleaned, it had dirty sheets on the bed that had clearly been slept in and mud on the carpet. This was rectied, but our subsequent room was dreadful. The mattress had springs you could feel through the sheets, and the edge of the mattress had collapsed. The whole hotel is worn out and everything needs replacing. The lts smell of stale cigarette smoke. The whole place has an unpleasant odour, possibly due to the smoking rooms, and cigarette smoke infiltrating the whole building. Avoid at all costs. Another user, Aidan, included pictures of a stained door handle and a stain on the floor, saying: Honestly, DO NOT STAY HERE! Rooms are filthy, unfit for purpose and theyaposre just an absolute joke all around. The lts look like they haven’t been replaced since the s. The hotel, which is only three miles from Manchester Airport, has , reviews, with more than , of these being apospoorapos or aposterribleapos and only  being aposexcellentapos. Consumer watchdog Which  ranked it at the bottom of a league table of  large hotel chains. The survey of , hotel guests over  months to October , left Britannia with just  points out of a possible . Despite this, not everyone has had a bad experience at the Airport Hotel, with one recent guest saying it was absolutely fine. One read: Our room was fine. Clean, warm and quite spacious actually but the bed was a bit old and uncomfortable. Other than that itaposs dficult for us to really find fault. We had a burger and chips from the bar which was perfectly edible and we only stayed in the room for just over  hours. Itaposs not The Ritz and the room decor was a bit tired but for our purposes, the Britannia was absolutely fine. Another recent review added: Perfect for our needs for an early flight from Manchester airport! The room is cleana little basic but plenty space for our family! The reception staff are very friendly and efficient and the bar very welcoming! Suited our needs perfectly! Great value for airport parking too! Thecontacted Britannia Hotels for comment. title: ordinary three bed terraced home
story: Ordinary three-bed terraced home hides incredible PALACE in living roomThe terraced home with  bedrooms is located in Christchurch, Dorset and was listed on the market on TuesdayA -bedroom property with a palatial Roman-style living room has been listed on the market for £,ByRuaraidh GilmourLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Mar |commentsA three-bed property with a palatial Roman-style living room has been listed on the market for £,. The terraced home in Christchurch, Dorset was listed on the market on Tuesday March . The large living room takes up over half of the downstairs and its main feature is a detailed ceiling painting that depicts angels flying and sitting on clouds. The depiction is bordered with round gold and blue trim with ious patterns.  A bust of a woman stands tall at the back of the room, while gold trimmed patterned chairs and couches are positioned next to the light blue walls. There is a marble coffee table that sits on an old fashioned royal-looking carpet whilst a large gold rimmed mirror hangs on the back wall. Breaking the Roman theme, there is a flat screen TV hung from the wall and a guitar amplier resting on one of the chairs.  Leaving the lavish room, the rest of the house appears to be far more common. The kitchen is of a good size and has a double glass door that leads to the garden. Two of the three bedrooms are of good size and can comfortably accommodate double beds, while the third room could only fit a single bed.  The only bathroom in the property is situated upstairs and has a large bath and a separate shower. In their listing on Rightmove, Goadsby, who are managing the property wrote: A spacious terraced home situated in a popular area being just yards from Two Riversmeet Leisure Centre with its golf course. Christchurch town centre is also easily accessible.  There is a covered entrance porch which has a storage cupboard, a door leads through to the lounge. The lounge is a good size with a front aspect window. A door leads through to the kitchen breakfast room which has ample space for a dining table whilst also having a good range of wall and floor cupboards with working surfaces over... There are  doubles, both having fitted cupboards and Bedroom  is currently used as an office.  The bathroom benefits from a corner bath with separate shower cubicle, pedestal wash hand basin and low level w.c. One social media user saw the unique living room and decided to share it on Reddit: For just £k you can enjoy the wonders of the Sistine Chapel from the comfort of your own living room. The post has over  likes and has been commented on over a dozen times.Reddit users found the living room amusing.@Grumpyandproud said: I was not prepared for that living room. @Keiepse wrote: aposThe lounge is a good size with a front aspect window.aposAmazing that the agent couldnapost think of anything  for the description. @Leftpillz commented: Itaposs a pretty appropriate design given the cityaposs name, Christchurch. @Nicowltan replied: That living room is insane, but Iaposm a big fan of the dog at the back door.@busyphil added: Wow. I love the way the description doesnapost reference that ceiling at all. title: pandemic heroes can help level
story: Pandemic heroes can help us level up country and bring communities togetherWe are days away now from the second anniversary of lockdown. Two years on, we have seen communities come together, neighbours look out for one other and groups form across the UKCharles Burrell Centre manager Nik Chapman, outside the centre in Thetford Image: MATTHEW USHERByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnistClaire Donnelly:,  Mar |comments At the peak of the pandemic, on the Henley Green estate in Coventry, residents got used to the sight of two top-of-the-range Jaguars delivering food.The local community centre had turned its ‘Grub Hub service’ into a delivery service for isolating residents. As it grew from  members to supporting , people, they had asked local business for support. “Jaguar Land Rover let us use two of their vehicles,” says Dianne Williams, , CEO of the Moat House Trust. “We went out delivering meals in these two white jags. It was brilliant.”We are days away now from the second anniversary of lockdown. Two years on, we have seen communities come together, neighbours look out for one other and groups form across the UK. Never mind that – to use words of one campaigning organisation – we were led by donkeys. The British public were lions – acting as a pride. This week, the Mirror has been celebrating working class solidarity and community spirit after revisiting our  Wigan Pier Project journey. Now, we are paying tribute to those who stepped up during the pandemic. From the Knowle West Alliance who fed people in Bristol, to an advice delivery service in Berwick-on-Tweed, to the Levy Corona Helpers in Manchester’s Levenshulme and Centre in Grimsby, this was a national effort carried out at grassroots level. Hyper-local micro-miracles that have changed the face of Britain. Over , mutual aid groups – modelled on systems of support used by black radicals in America – provided solidarity, not charity, supported by a staggering three million volunteers. Existing community projects transformed their provision. Trade unions turned out volunteers, as well as getting workers furloughed and preventing redundancies.  The Mirror teamed up with the Red Cross for a Kindness Will Keep Us Together campaign and more than , signed up. From driving people to hospital appointments to delivering essential medicines, more than , acts of kindness were carried out across the country in just the first four months of lockdown.More than , people signed up to the NHS volunteer scheme. In the first three weeks of lockdown, , people signed up to become community volunteers. More than , people donated their time in  to support the vaccine rollout.Groups formed to help with food shopping and food parcels, collecting prescriptions and providing dog walking. They helped tackle loneliness, were a source of trustworthy Covid information, set up community gardens, and much more. But most importantly, in dark times, every act of kindness was a beacon of hope. The Charles Burrell Centre in Thetford, Norfolk, became a hub for mutual aid that has never ended. “We had a lady in this week enquiring about eligibility for fuel voucher,” Nik Chapman, CEO of The Charles Burrell Centre in Thetford, says. “In the last eight weeks, she only switched her heating on for Christmas Day and had been eating all food cold. She has been making extreme decisions to stay out of debt.”  The Centre provides a supermarket, a community fridge, a hygiene and a fuel bank – services accessed by around , people. “It’s not just about any food,” Nik says. “We need to combat diabetes, obesity and rickets. Le expectancy in this part of Thetford is  to  years less than the more affluent parts. Part of that is nutrition.” He adds: “% of the people who come are employed – a lot work at local supermarkets but they can’t afford to shop there.” Some  miles away in London, the Manor House Development Trust realised many families were unable to home school because they had no internet access. “People would usually come to our spaces to use the wi, but during the pandemic we couldn’t do that,” CEO Simon Donovan, , says. So, they crowdfunded to get residents old and young online. They delivered art packs to kelp kids learning and connected knitters and sewers who got to work making PPE. More than  volunteers gave out , pre-cooked meals to local residents – , kilos of food. Two years on, some Mutual Aid groups have already pivoted to help refugees from Afghanistan, and now Ukraine – putting our government to shame. Meanwhile, the crisis after the pandemic is only just beginning. Vulnerable families face rocketing bills. Many are far worse off than when they were furloughed, while others have lost the £ pandemic uplt to Universal Credit.This incredible network of local groups stands poised to help – but it faces its own challenges, from volunteer burn out to a lack of footfall in charity shops and cafes. Locality – which supports local community organisations – will publish a new report next week that will argue government should put communities in charge of its levelling up funding – including the Community Ownership Fund and UK Shared Prosperity Fund. “Two years ago, an amazing thing happened,” Tony Armstrong, chief exec of Locality, says. “At our hour of need, we looked to each other for help and rediscovered the awesome power of community. Now government, funders and other decision-makers must put their faith in these organisations and give them the powers and resources to get on with the job. There can be no levelling up without powering up community organisations everywhere.”  Done properly, what happened during the pandemic can be a blueprint for Levelling Up. Instead of reinventing the wheel with top-down, eye-catching schemes, the government should strengthen existing community-led projects. “I think we all know it is going to get worse,” Nik Chapman says. “The cost of pretty much everything is rocketing. Undoubtedly the tragedy in Ukraine will have an impact. It’s a crisis. But at least we can be there to say, ‘it’s not going to be alright, but at least you’re not alone’.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSRed CrossHospitalsChristmas shoppingSupermarketsCoronavirusDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus briefing with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: UK weather forecast: mph gales and heavy rain for weekend ahead of C scorcherThe UK is set for blustery conditions over the coming days with gale force winds reaching mph on Saturday before the temperature rises next week and could reach a balmy C by WednesdayGale force winds are predicted for this weekend Image: Colin Lane Liverpool EchoByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar |commentsBrits are facing heavy rain and mph gales this weekend before temperatures rise and could reach a balmy C in the sunshine by the middle of next week.After an icy start to March there are finally signs that we could be heading towards spring with the mercury climbing although there is still plenty of unsettled weather over the coming days with gale force winds and rain.A spike in temperatures saw parts of the UK warmer than Athens on Thursday and it will remain mild on Friday but a cooler wind means that highs are likely to be around C or C. It is a blustery outlook for the weekend with a mixed bag before warm weather pushes north. BBC weather forecaster Tomasz Schafernaker said: The last couple of days the weather really has been quite good, beautul sunny skies for some of us across eastern parts of the UK but things are probably going to turn now. The cloud you can see on the satellite image is a weather front and it’s approaching. It means rain, and really that’s how it is going to be over the next few days.” Looking at Friday he said that there will be heavy rain sweeping in and winds will start to strengthen during the day but it will remain mild. Mr Schafernaker continued: “Now Saturday we see another area of low pressure with new fronts approaching us and this again spells heavy rain initially for western parts of the UK. In the South West as this low pressure increases you can see strong winds blowing around and we could be talking about gusts of mph, maybe even mph around the Isle of Scilly and the top of Cornwall, so really very blustery and even stormy for a time.  Next week we are expecting the temperatures to rise even as high as C or C in south west parts of the UK. Fellow BBC weather forecaster Sarah Keith-Lucas agreed: Moving forward to the start of the new working week, heading on into Monday and it looks like eventually we will lose that low pressure to the north of the UK and we will be seeing a bit of quieter spell of weather for Monday, so less windy for most of us. Still a little bit windy and showery across Scotland first thing and we could see a few spells of light rain across parts of England and Wales but it looks like that should fizzle out during the day and temperatures should [be] C or C, double figures further north.  “But the milder weather is on the way it’s moving its way in from the south moving into Tuesday.” She continued: Tuesday potentially bringing a little bit of rain in the south and the east at first that looks like it will fade away leaving a predominantly dry day with some sunshine, less breezy … best of the sunshine further south and east with temperatures up to about C.” UK forecast for the next  days Windy today with rain moving northeastwards followed by showers. Today: Early cloud and patchy rain in the north and east clearing to sunny spells for a time before cloud and rain . In the south and west, early rain, heavy at times, followed by sunny spells and showers later. Windy. Tonight: Often rather cloudy with showers or longer spells of rain, heaviest and most frequent showers probably over southern, western and central parts during the early hours. Becoming less windy. Saturday: Sunny spells and showers for many, though showers will tend to ease from the south later. Dull, wet and windy weather developing in the west and southwest during the afternoon. Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday: Unsettled on Sunday with showers or rain, wettest and windiest in the northwest, some brighter spells too. Drier for most on Monday and Tuesday, though rain in the northwest. Dozens of users have also commented on the video, with many sharing that they didnapost know about the packaging and that the aposfun factapos made lots of sense. While an Aldi employee added that they loved impressing people with their speed at the till, saying: This is the most satisfying part of my job. story: Little girl with beautul voice made the world weep for children of UkraineThere has never been a more powerful version of Let It Go, Polly Hudson says of the footage from an underground bunker, reminding us how lives have been turned upside down for millions of innocentsAmelia singing in the bunker Image: PAopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Mar |commentsIt’s the chaos surrounding her that you notice first. The ­desperate families squeezed in, standing, sitting, lying wherever they can, next to their precariously piled ­belongings, packed into the dank underground space they now call home. There’s an air of restlessness, a palpable sense of tension and anxiety. How could there not be And then, completely unexpectedly, something magical happens. Little Amelia – age unknown, but probably, what, seven or eight  – stands up on a chair. She’s wearing a sparkly jumper with stars on it, from HM a few years ago – my friend’s daughter has the same one and still loves it too. Hands clenched together shyly, unbrushed hair pulled back into a ponytail, Amelia plucks up all her courage, opens her mouth and starts to sing Let It Go, from Frozen. And like a spell cast in the movie her song comes from, the Kyiv shelter falls silent. Everyone turns and gives this small blonde scrap of a girl their mesmerised full attention. No one moves. Babies stop crying. This captive audience cannot take their eyes off her, as they listen to her sweet, steady voice, a chink of shining light in the unimaginable ­darkness of Ukraine.She has given these people the gt of focusing on something other than the living nightmare they’re enduring, albeit briefly, and there isn’t a dry eye in the room. Or from any of the millions around the globe who have since watched the video on social media.Despite probably never having heard Ukrainian before, the song is in the universal language of Disney, kids from any country in the world watching it could name that tune in three. In the caption, the woman who posted it explains that Amelia told her she wanted to be “a singer on a grand stage” – an ambition now fulfilled, just not in a way anyone would want. Their poor parents can, at least, try to fight back, but the children of Ukraine are utterly defenceless in this war. Putin is torturing and traumatising these pure, faultless human beings, turning them into orphans. Murdering  of them.  Amelia and the other kids in that shelter, and similar ones across the country. Danya and Mpak, the boys trapped in Calais, denied entry by our callous government because they don’t have the right paperwork. The -year-old who braved a -mile journey to safety alone. Heroic President Volodymyr Zelensky’ s own children – Aleksandra, , and Kiril, age nine – who have targets on their backs. Polina, the girl with the pink hair, and her brother Semyon, both dead. And the many other nameless young casualties.All entirely blameless, innocent children – just like their entirely blameless, innocent mums and dads – frightened for their lives.  Two weeks ago they were moaning about homework, playing with their friends, not eating their vegetables. Now, suddenly plunged into a reality where growing up without their fathers may well be the best case scenario. The least worst of their horrendous options. When Let It Go lyricist Kristen Anderson-Lopez saw Amelia’s rendition, she tweeted: “Dear Little Girl with the beautul voice, my husband and I wrote this song. The way you sing it is like a magic trick that spreads the light in your heart and heals everyone who hears it.” She finished by urging Amelia to “Keep singing!” If only that choice was hers. news world-news russian-state-tv-broadcasts-stinging-"Zelensky urges Russians to speak out against PutinByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Mar Updated:,  Mar |comments Russian state TV guests have hit out at the invasion of Ukraine and risked the wrath of Vladimir Putin by defying him on a popular primetime show.Thousands of people have been protesting in Russian cities following the invasion of their neighbouring country, with many seeing Ukrainians as their brothers, and authorities have threatened critics of the war with  years in jail. But with state media having backed the Ukrainian invasion the majority of Russians appear to seemingly be in support - and it is Putinaposs control over journalists that has helped him to rule without any signicant opposition. Now, though, on a programme hosted by Vladimir Soloviyev, a staunch supporter of Putin’s regime, guests openly criticised the attack on Ukraine with one saying it was like “Afghanistan but even worse.” The use of Afghanistan as an example is signicant in Russia as it is seen as a military humiliation - with the country having spent  years in the country before withdrawing in . Soloviyev has been pedalling state propaganda even agreeing that the shelling of a maternity hospital in Mariupol this week was “fake news” - claiming the building was now being used by Ukraine troops.He was left fuming, though, by comments on his Thursday night show where they questioned what the Russians were doing in Ukraine.Karen Shakhbnazarov, a filmmaker and political commentator, took a dig at the decision to invade Ukraine on the Russia  channel. “The war in Ukraine paints a frightening picture, it has a very oppressive influence on our society. Ukraine, whichever way you see it, is somewhere with which Russia has thousands of human links, he said, reported the Daily Beast.  The suffering of one group of innocents does not compensate for the suffering of other innocent people... I don’t see the probability of denazication of such an enormous country. We would need to bring in . million soldiers to control all of it. He added: The most important thing in this scenario is to stop our military action. Shakhbnazarov did toe the country’s line that the war was caused by the United States but he said that a “humanitarian disaster” would also see Russia’s allies like China and India distancing themselves.  The host, who is one the Russians to have been sanctioned by the EU and has had an Italian villa seized, was left annoyed by the analysis but other guests were also critical. Semyon Bagdasarov, a Russian Middle East expert, agreed with Shakhbnazarov and said that Russians need to prepare for total isolation. He drew the parallels with Afghanistan saying: Let Ukrainians do this denazication on their own. We can’t do it for them... As for their neutrality, yes, we should squeeze it out of them, and that’s it.  We don’t need to stay there longer than necessary... Do we need to get into another Afghanistan, but even worse  There are more people and they’re more advanced in their handling of weapons. We don’t need that. Enough already... As for the sanctions, the world has never seen such massive sanctions.” Other media shows have also given an insight into the war casualties in Ukraine with Russian soldiers dying, which is also going against the official line that the battle is going according to plan. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.There#s a mix of positive news and other stories which are more on the depressing side this week.Costs are definitely rising across the board # from council tax to electricity and food to fuel # which makes it all the more important to look out for each other as times get tougher.The leblood of our rural communities is our local shops and services, andwe continue to support local, they might just be there to support us in the longer term.But enough depression.How good is it to see our events and festivals planning tothis year If the past couple of years have taught us anything it#s that you never know what#s round the corner. title: march gardening tips it starts with a seed
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowIn a week or two it will be March, which will hopefully bring some sunny days to tempt gardeners back into the garden # and many of us are really aching for spring now.This is the month for sowing seeds and getting the garden ready for the summer.But, before you rush to get sowing, take time to plan what you want to grow, how many plants you are going to need and when you want them to flower or bear fruit. This is particularly good advice for anyone with a veg plot.A sowing plan of what seeds and how many to sow each month is key to successful growing and means you won#t be throwing out unwanted seedlings and that your flower and veg beds will be full all year round.A word of warning about sowing direct into the ground at this time of year there may be a few sunny days to enjoy outside but the soil can still be chilly, making germination and survival hard.Sowing indoors is a better option. Not only does it provide a warm environment for germination, but seeds and seedlings are easier to protect from pests. If you can find some environmentally sound sowing trays and containers, rather than using plastic, that#s even better. Paper and cardboard pots can be packed snugly in a tray which avoids over handling and makes them easy to water.Small seeds should be scattered sparingly on the surface of compost filled seed trays then covered with a sprinkling of sieved compost. If the seeds are big enough to handle, you can sow them inidually into cm pots. The quantity should be according to the instructions specied on the seed packet, but usually for small seeds between five and  seeds per pot. For plants that grow long roots, such as peas or beans, you can put them into a compost filled cardboard toilet roll tube and, once ready, they can be planted outside, tube and all.Most seeds will germinate and grow in a warm setting such as a greenhouse, cold frame or on a sunny windowsill. You should keep them damp by using a mist spray to start with before moving onto a watering can with a fine rose nozzle.Once the seedlings have grown their second pair of leaves and before they get too squashed in seed trays or pots, pot them on into small pots. Simply ease out a clump of seedlings with an old cutlery fork or dibber and # handling only the leaves to avoid damaging delicate stems and roots # gently tease them apart. Drop inidual seedlings into a five-centimetre compost filled newspaper pot ensuring the lower leaves are above the compost level. Once you see roots appearing from the bottom of the pot, it’s time to pot on to a bigger pot before planting outside once the weather and soil warms up.If you are growing your own veg, now is a good time to sow first early potatoes. These can be planted from mid-March, however planting times will y across the country according to temperature and risk of frost. Early potatoes grow well in the ground and in containers such as potato grow bags or old compost bags. You should plant your chitted potatoes with the shoots facing upwards in soil with plenty of well-rotted organic matter, approximately cms deep and cms apart.Once stems are about cms tall, they will need earthing up by drawing soil around them to create a cm high ridge, to protect against frost and keep growing potatoes covered. Good ieties of early potatoes are: Swt # good for containers, white skinned and white fleshed Annabelle # nutty flavour with firm waxy yellow flesh and Maris Bard # white flesh with good #new potato# flavour and drought resistance.Spring seems tantalisingly close in March, particularly as work in the garden starts to get going again.According to the Royal Horticultural Society, spring usually arrives by mid-March and the frequent sunny days provide the opportunity for an increasing range of gardening tasks. It#s time to get busy preparing seed beds, sowing seed, cutting back winter shrubs and generally tidying up around the garden.Top three jobs in March:PICS:Once the seedlings have grown their second pair of leaves and before they get too squashed in seed trays or pots, pot them on into small pots. no_aGardening_March

GHK broke the deadlock to score the first try of the game  minutes into the game, then missed the conversion.Mid Argyll then put together some great attacking plays and earned a penalty just outside the GHK -metre line.Inside centre Coll MacKay stepped up to score Mid Argyll#s first points of the campaign with a glorious conversion.  –  to GHK.GHK went on to score two more tries and one conversion # before disaster struck for Mid Argyll on the stroke of half time and with the score at  –  to GHK, as Wilson hobbled off with suspected knee ligament damage.With Wilson playing out of position in the front row, Mid Argyll had to reshuffle an already patchwork pack with Aaron McAllister moving from the wing to hooker and usual hooker Robbie Herd moving to prop.The new look front row finished off, Daniel Doherty doing well, as they held their own against an experienced opposition pack.Mid Argyll took time to settle into the new system, though, and GHK ran in two more converted tries.Mid Argyll almost produced the perfect reply when fly-half Logan Allen whipped a quick ball out to Gritten who, without actually catching the ball, flicked it on to Innes Patterson.Patterson beat two players and released Ed King-Venables who was caught by the GHK defence just short of the line.GHK ran the ball back up field but some great defensive play from flanker Gordon McLean, Self and MacArthur stopped them on the halfway line.A scrum to Mid Argyll saw scrum-half Calum Patterson pick the ball from the feet of McLean and, noticing a gap in the defence, broke through.He still had two more players to beat before he ran over the whitewash for Mid Argyll#s first try of the season # undoubtedly try of the match. MacKay converted for another two points and the score was  –  GHK.Having played with no subs, fatigue was starting to set in for the Argyll boys and with GHK using their subs they ran in a few more breakaway tries.Towards the end of the game GHK had one last attempt and broke through the Argyll defence, but from nowhere C Patterson found the determination and energy to chase the attacker down and fling out an arm to ankle tap him five metres short of the line and supporting was Lochlain Ellis to compete for the ball and earn Mid Argyll a deserved penalty.The final whistle sounded shortly after and the game finished  - to GHK.Mid Argyll enjoyed great hospitality from hosts GHK and Innes Patterson was awarded man of the match before the long journey home.

title: science matters another unwelcome invader 2
story: Dorothy H CrawfordUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowMost of us are active by day and rest by night, but within these confines there are several possibilities ranging from larksto owls .These preferences, called chronotypes, have a genetic basis that controls one#s biological clock, but this can be modied by ious factors such as light exposure, age and lestyle.However, when the genetic and environmental cues are not aligned a chronic condition known as #social jetlag# may ensue.This problem is exacerbated during adolescence when chronotypes become increasingly delayed, but schools start early in the morning.This can cause sleep loss that may lead to major health and psychological problems and also affect academic performance.In a recent study scientists examined how the interaction between chronotype and school start time influenced inidual academic performance* by taking advantage of a high school system where  students had been randomly assigned to lessons in the morning , afternoonor evening .This enabled the unbiased testing of the effect of chronology and school schedules on academic performance in adolescents aged - years and - years.The results showed that among the early morning group, very few students got adequate sleep.The larksoutperformed owlsin all school subjects and this effect, which increased as students progressed through the school, was most extreme in maths.This outcome, however, was not evident in those having afternoon schooling, and the situation almost reversed in those receiving evening schooling, where students with later chronotypes performed slightly better in languages than the early chronotypes in the same group.Clearly academic performance is influenced by biological iation in daily rhythms, to an extent that has previously been underestimated.The study authors, while conceding that it is impractical to attempt to fully align school timetables to inidual chronotypes, suggest that it may be possible to, for example, progressively delay school start times during adolescence.* Goldin et al.  https:doi.org . s---.

title: in columbas footsteps without cuban heels
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowA TV series will feature Mid Argyll as it follows seven celebrities on a pilgrimage through Ireland, Northern Ireland and Scotland.#Pilgrimage# follows the celebs # of dferent faiths and none # for  days as they follow in the footsteps of Saint Columba, seeking out his legacy as a key figure in early British Christianity, helping spread the faith from Ireland to Scotland and beyond.Along the way Will Bayley, Scarlett Moffat, Monty Panesar, Louisa Clein, Laurence Lewellyn-Bowen, Shazia Mirza and Nick Hewer enjoyed the hospitality of the people of Knapdale.They arrived in Achahoish on September  last year, having set off from Northern Ireland the previous day by boat.Tired and weary, the pilgrims were welcomed into South Knapdale Parish Church at Achahoish, where they met with some of the congregation and shared a meal.South Knapdale Parish Church Minister Reverend David Carruthers explained: #The programme#s producers # and the visitors # had caught wind of the fact that the church in Achahoish has been used previously by pilgrim groups passing through.#The Presbytery of Argyll#s youth workers have previously arranged pilgrim walks under the banner of the Columba Experience and the church at Achahoish was used for accommodation on two successive years.#After their meal at Achahoish, the group started to share with one another something of their backgrounds, beliefs and faiths whilst the TV cameras rolled.After three hours of fascinating chat, the locals went home and the travellers bedded down on the church floors in their sleeping bags.Next day the pilgrims headed northwards via Columba#s Cave near Ellary, where Father Simon MacKenzie of Christchurch in Lochgilphead conducted a short act of worship.The celebrity pilgrims began their journey in Donegal before travelling to Argyll. From Knapdale, they headed up the west coast, sailing to Lewis and Harris before arriving at their final destination, Iona.Covering almost , miles in the series, they visit places of worship, from pagan stones to an early Christian cave and a contemporary mosque and Sikh temple. The journey tests the pilgrims not just spiritually, but physically too.TV celeb and comedian Scarlett Moffatt, , said: #At school, I spent a lot of time just reading books and on my own and so that’s how I got into faith really. It just felt calming. There’s almost a stigma attached to sort of being religious.#Whenever I would tell my friends, they’d laugh and I’d be like, #why is that funny # I believe in God, there has to be something that started all this.#I would describe myself as Christian, but not a strict Christian. I don’t go to church, but I definitely believe and religion to me is security.#She added: #In my head somebody on a pilgrimage is in a loin cloth and they have really long hair#and they look a bit dehydrated like they need a good moisturiser mask.#I’m doing the pilgrimage as I want to know what my religion is. I want to be able to answer that question with confidence.#TV personality and interior designer Laurence Lewellyn-Bowen describes himself as a #non-conforming pagan#. The -year-old explained: #I think pilgrimage is about clearing out your mental closet by physical exertion and by spiritual conversation with yourself or,you believe it, then conversation with your God.#I know I come across as all sort of flouncy and floppy and rather cavalier, but I am capable of existing in the real world.#However, I don’t think I’ve walked so far not wearing Cuban heels.#Pilgrimage: The Road to the Scottish Isles will be screened on BBC Two and iPlayer in the spring with three one-hour-long episodes, and is a CTVC production.

title: france-currently-best-team-world-murrayfield-performance-suggests-yes
story: FRANCE lived up to the pre-match assessment of Scotland’s head coach Gregor Townsend as currently the best team in the world.BT Murrayfield was in fine voice as captain Rachel Malcolm and centre Helen Nelson – fresh from their - victory over Columbia in Dubai yesterday, which ensured qualication for the Rugby World Cup in New Zealand in October delivered the match ball.Melvyn Jaminet missed an early penalty due to the gusting winds, but the visitors were soon in the lead after Paul Willemse crashed over for a try which Jaminet converted.Straight from the restart, Hawick man Darcy Graham made an audacious mid-air catch and Scotland were soon on the board as Fin Russell kicked a penalty.Jaminet then took advantage of the new : kick rule and from the resultant pressure Yoram Moefana crash over for the visitors’ second try, the left wing scoring on the right. Jaminet missed the conversion.A challenge by Jaminet on Stuart McInally then had the Scots fans raging. Initially, referee Karl Dickson allowed play to continue but after checking with the TMO awarded Scotland a penalty and ruled that was sufficient sanction.Ali Price appeared to be over for Scotlands first try, in spite of a high tackle but the ball had not been grounded.Scotland were now camped in the French  and from Nick Haining’s surge, Price fed former Southern Knight Rory Darge who crashed over for his first try for Scotland on his first start. Russell converted.Scotland then missed a great chance when Chris Harris threw a miss-two pass to Stuart Hogg but, agonisingly the ball spilled it forward and a golden try chance was lost for Scotland.Just before the break France extended their lead when Fickou beat the tackles of Price and Haining to touch down at the corner flag and Jaminet converted from the touchline.France extended their lead shortly after the break when a kick forward bounced awkwardly into the path of Jonathan Danty who ran in for the bonus point try. Jaminet grabbed the extras..removePenaud then romped in for try number five and although Jaminet missed the conversion everyone knew the game was lost.France added a sixth try in  minutes after Romain Ntamack’s cross-field kick, found Penaud who had a simple task.Scotland did pull back a try at the death after Blair Kinghorn’s break was rounded off by van der Merwe, who dotted down his tenth try for his country. Hogg converted.But it was too little to late for the Scots and the French ran out - winners.

title: enduro-world-series-return-innerleithen-summer
story: ELITE athletes from across the world are set toto Peeblesshire for a mountain bike festival this summer.The Enduro World Serieswas held in Innerleithen last year following a six-year hiatus.And organisers want the event – which reportedly brought , people to the area last time out – to be “even bigger” this year.Event director Emma Wadee said: “We can’t wait to bring EWS back to Innerleithen this summer.“Our aim is to build on last year’s success to make EWS Tweed Valley one of Scotland’s best international events that celebrates the region and local community, as well as attracting visitors from around the world.”Organisers say it will be a “weekend of racing, entertainment, live music, local food, kids events, ride outs, film nights and more”.The festival is due toon June  until June  this year.Businesses and residents will receive communications about the event in the coming weeks, including letters and packs.Meanwhile there is a planned ‘town hall’ event on Thursday, April  in the Union Club.As well as attracting some of mountain biking’s top athletes, the festival could also give Peeblesshire businesses a major boost.Ahead of last year’s event, council officers said that the biking spectacle could have an “economic impact of £.m for the area”.Meanwhile, Enduro Sports Organisation – the company behind the EWS – is set to open its global headquarters in Innerleithen later this year.It follows an extensive renovation of a property on the town’s Chapel Street.From there, its growing team will coordinate the global race series, which has mountain bike events in over  countries.

title: paralympicsgb-curlers-face-norway-usa-day-one-beijing
story: ParalympicsGB’s wheelchair curlers began their campaign at the Ice Cube with a closely contested - defeat to a strong Norway.The team of Hugh Nibloe, Gregor Ewan, Meggan Dawson-Farrell and Duns man David Melrose fought their way back from - down to tie the match before Norway took a decisive lead in the penultimate end.They had the chance to draw level with the last stone but it was not to be and Norway took the fixture.Later that day they faced a USA team who had also lost their opening match and it was another closely fought contest.USA raced in to a - lead then the momentum swung back and forth before a brilliant take out by Gregor Ewan gave ParalmypicsGB the lead for the first time in the penultimate end and they closed out the match to win -.The team were scheduled to face RPCtoday but that fixture was cancelled when the Russians were refused permission to take part.Afterwards Skip Hugh Nibloe said: ‘United States and Norway are good teams so to come out today won one and lost one is probably fair and it was so important to get that first win.“It was so important especially for Meggan and David being their first Paralympics to get that belief that we can win games and we know we are goGregor Ewan added: ‘USA is always a very hard match for us they never get a big win against us and we never get a big win against them“It’s always hard after a defeat but we went out for a push and got some fresh air before coming back in.“We have found getting moving and getting our brains in to gear helps – we have some games we are playing in the changing room just to try and keep us switched on“The round robin stage is never easy we know we need five to six wins to be close to qualying.
