title: Ballynahinch have day to forget against Bangor side in league outing
story: BALLYNAHINCH fell to a - defeat at the hands of a visiting Bangor side in the Ulster Intermediate League.The first quarter began and Bangor were quick to put the pressure on lsquoHinch down the wings but were duly stopped in their tracks by Lewis Higginson and Ben Chadwick.lsquoHinch were keen to keep Bangor out of their circle with strong defending from Ashley Brown, Leslie Harrison, Andrew Mulholland and lsquokeeper Aaron Donnell.Bangor were able to create chances but couldnrsquot convert. Matthew Martin played around several Bangor defenders and looked to pass up to Jason Campbell up front, who got into some promising positions.However, it was Bangor who broke the deadlock following a cross to the back post to take the lead.Play continued with both teams creating chances but neither were able to add to the scoreline before the end of the quarter.Bangor continued to apply pressure on lsquoHinch from the start of the second but the home side managed to manufacture counterattacks.lsquoHinch were playing the ball down the wings to Adam Dodds and Ross Connolly.Leslie Harrison played the ball out from the back to Andrew McIlwaine, only to be dispossessed by the Bangor defence.Play became end to end with teams trying to keep possession but unable to do so. Bangor were able to scoretheir second of the day just before half-time with a deflection in a crowded circle.lsquoHinch started the third quarter with a quick push back and passed the ball up the pitch towards Bangorrsquos goal only to be met by a strong defence.Matthew Martin worked the ball up the pitch, passing to Jason Campbell and Adam Dodds allowing them to have some shots towards the Bangor goal.Hugo Melville, Ross Connolly and Ben Chadwick kept the pressure on Bangor players tackling when possible.Aaron Donnell continued to get his touch to send many balls wide of the lsquoHinch goal. Bangor scored their third goal from open play, although many of the lsquoHinch defence disputed the previous foul. The umpire awarded the goal.lsquoHinch reset and continued with the end to end play for the remainder of the quarter. Bangor were awarded a short corner and were able to find the back of the net to leave the score -.Ballynahinch kept plugging away in the final quarter and each time the ball was lost, they immediately turned and faced Bangor in defensive mode.Ross Connolly, Hugo Melville and Ben Chadwick continued to mark and tackle the Bangor players right to the end of the quarter.Scott Leech was able to hit the ball up the pitch and into the Bangor net. Unfortunately, it was hit from outside the Bangor circle.The Hinch defence worked hard throughout the last quarter continuing to push the ball out of the circle and up towards the midfield and forwards.However, Just before the final whistle Bangor were able to notch their fth goal of the match and ultimately rounded off the scoring..prettyPhoto

title: Behind closed doors Festival of Flight talk
story: LOCAL politicians have discussed in secret the possibility of staging the highly acclaimed Festival of Flight in Newcastle next year.At Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos monthly meeting on Monday night, the media and public were barred from a behind-closed-doors discussion on staging the flagship tourist event next summer after the plug was pulled on this yearrsquos event.The Recorder understands that potential costings of staging the international aviation festival mdash which is headlined by the Red Arrows mdash were not discussed during the secret debate.Before the issue was discussed in private, council officials argued that it would be ldquopremature to determine the organisationrsquos   events programme before costings had been determined.When the press were readmitted to the online meeting, it was confirmed that the local authority would work towards putting the Festival of Flight into the   events programme, subject to approval from its Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.Several weeks ago, the decision to ground this yearrsquos festival was also taken in secret, with the Ulster Aviation Society, which has played a major role since the inaugural festival, describing its disappointment at the cancellation decision.The Society said it was ldquodisappointed and dismayed about the cancellation of the airshow and the fact that the organisation had not been consulted with the organisationrsquos chairman, Ray Burrows, saying it was ldquoastonishing that the event had been ldquoshot down in secret, with no reasonable explanation.On Monday night, Cllrs Glyn Hanna, Kathryn Owen and David Taylor said they were keen to secure a firm commitment that everything would be done to ensure that the aviation spectacular, which draws up to , visitors to Newcastle and provides a major boost for the local economy, would go ahead next summer. The festival was last held in .Cllr Hanna said that while it was disappointing that this yearrsquos event would not be going ahead, a number of suggestions for an alternative festival had been made. He asked that that all Mournes area councillors are consulted before anything is agreed for this summer in Newcastle.ldquoThere is a substantial amount of money available and Mournes councillors should have a massive say in what happens in Newcastle this year, he added, with his suggestion backed by Cllr Leeanne McEvoy.Cllr Owen proposed that a firm commitment should be made to include the Festival of Flight in the councilrsquos events calendar for next year.She said she had been contacted by a number of business owners and aviation enthusiasts who were concerned that this yearrsquos festival had been cancelled and hoped that it will proceed next summer.Council deputy chief executive Dorinnia Carville said it would be would be premature to determine the events programme for   ahead of finding out how much it would cost.The council official said the organisation had to go through the rates process each year and look at budgets thereafter.Several weeks ago, it was confirmed that this yearrsquos Festival of Flight would not go ahead due to the challenges in planning such a major festival, securing commitments from participants and with the uncertainty caused to date by the coronavirus pandemic.The international festival was cancelled in  because of bad weather and was also grounded in  and last year because of the Covid- pandemic..prettyPhoto

title: Down on the Farm book shows importance of museum collections detailing rich history
story: lsquoI SAW the man jump out of the group and grasp the handles of the plough. He steadied himself and began to address his companions.lsquoHe lted one hand and pointed ahead. He named the parts. He spoke of horses and ploughing points. He strained and balanced and explained. Against the grey stone wall of the old gaol yard he conjured up the green fields of another le.lsquoOne of the nurses who came with the visiting party said to me: ldquoDo you know, thatrsquos the first time he has spoken for three years.rsquoThese words opened a chapter in the book Down on the Farm, published by Down County Museum in .They were specially chosen to help us understand that museum collections and activities are not just static objects or exercises in nostalgia. While museums are about objects, those objects have no signicance without people.People make things for particular purposes they use them, they value them, they discard them, they contemplate them. Museums try to understand objects in order to reach the peoplebehind them, understand their lives and so add meaning to our own.Local museums are concerned with all aspects of their communities. Their collections represent the inheritance, the culture, and the trust of their communities.Down County Museum has the largest collection of objects relating to farming in Ulster outside the national museums.Through the generosity of iniduals and families it has acquired not only the complete equipment of two of the last horse-powered farms in the county but a fine example of an early Ferguson tractor, with an invention which not only revolutionised agriculture but brought recognition to its County Down inventor throughout the world.A host of other items represent the history of a basic industry and developing way of le in County Down, from a wooden plough from Mourne to a donkey-powered milk churn from Ballyroney to the first reaper and binder in the area, to hay sweeps, rakes and potato diggers, scythes, rope twisters, turnip cutters, barn fans, churns, butter pats, sheep shears, horse harness, slipes, carts, Young Farmersrsquo Club trophies and records, and valuable medals given for agricultural improvements on the iable soils of County Down.We should not forget that we build on what has gone before and that is as true of our most important industry as of any other.One object which is almost entirely forgotten was the block-wheeled car, with solid wooden wheels, which was the ubiquitous load carrier before the introduction of the large-wheeled lsquoScotch cartrsquo in the s.The agricultural census of  recorded  of these lsquocarsrsquo in the  townlands of the south Ards alone. Imagine ourselves into that dferent world from which we have come. Think not only of the making of carts and the breeding and care of horses but also of the recycling of enormous amounts of dung.Museum staff managed to locate three of the last of these lsquotrottlersquo or lsquotrucklersquo cars and preserve the evidence of their construction. As with all aspects of museum work, this required both local and specialist knowledge, active travelling around the area and respectful relationships with the community.The museum developed a unique relationship with the community that was based on valuing and understanding the importance of lsquopeople and placersquo. The generous support of the community has been instrumental in creating the award-winning treasure-house that is the Down County Museum..prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick Family Autism Group fundraising to help get new home
story: A FUNDRAISING drive towards establishing a new base has been launched by Downpatrick Autism Family Support Group.The group aims to raise pound, over the next year to create a centre in the town for its dedicated use.The supports  families with at least one child which has autism.Project co-ordinator Aine Sloan explained that parents believe the centre is needed for the development of their children and the group in general.ldquoWe want to make a practical dference to the children and young people and their families by providing a strong support network, she said.ldquoOur activities and events are a good way for families to get to talk to one another and realise they are not alone.ldquoIt is very important to have the opportunity to meet others who understand the daily challenges and struggles they face as a family. We want to remove the isolation felt by both autistic children and their families.The group proved a leline to parents and children when it continued to provide activities and support to them over the lockdowns.It organises a range of activities and courses such as monthly parent support groups specialised autism parent training, fun days out, summer scheme, music and occupational therapy and sibling events.It was founded in  over a cup of coffee by two parents who were felt there was no support for their families before and after a diagnosis of autism.Aine explained: ldquoThis initially started as a monthly cup of coffee and a chat but quickly blossomed into something bigger due to sheer determination of our parents to make a dference.ldquoDAFSG is managed by a small committee who are all parents of autistic children which now includes new as well as founding members. We offer support to over  local families with membership increasing weekly due to the demand for our support.ldquoWe know it will take more than pound, to establish the centre and to run it but we need to show our commitment to other potential capital funders that we can fundraise and support our activities.Aine said that the group managed so far by renting rooms in ious local centres, but it was not a option it wanted in the long term.ldquoThis is not ideal and provides no continuity for our families. It is very dficult for us to co-ordinate programmes with no set premises. With this in mind we now need to make our dream of having our very own dedicated autism support a reality, said Aine.ldquoIn order for us to be able to apply for large capital grants we need to raise money so we can match fund the grant.The group is set to hold its first event, a Glow Walk, at RGU GAA ground in Downpatrick this Saturday at .pm. The charge is pound per person, but free for under-s, and free glow bracelets will be provided.To register, visit https:www.eventbrite e ..prettyPhoto

title: Festival evening to include music and ceilidh dance in night of fun
story: THE countdown is on to the Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Grouprsquos festival evening of music and ceilidh dance which takes place next Wednesday, March , at Ballynahinchrsquos Millbrook Lodge Hotel at .pm.The festival evening was unable to take place for the past two years due to the coronavirus, with everyone associated with the group delighted that it is all systems go this month.The programme line-up includes singers, dancers and musicians and after the eveningrsquos formal programme, there will be a short break for refreshments.During the second part of the evening, there will be traditional ceilidh dances, called by Raymond Carroll to tunes played by Tom McGonigle and fellow musicians from Castlewellan on a range of instruments.Twinning group officials are disappointed that their French visitors from Lamorlaye and Spanish visitors from Vimianzo in the Galicia region of Spain are unable to join them for the festival evening, but look forward to welcoming them back to the district next September.This monthrsquos festival evening brings to an end another busy year for the twinning group and, thanks to to funding from Newry Mourne and Down Council, the group was able to fund six interactive art water colour painting workshops in the Rowallane Community Hub.Patricia McCormick from Killyleagh Artistic Holistic led the classes between November and February .Meanwhile, Irish For All classes have been running in Ballynahinch Market House from September with students ranging in age from  to .Community group officials say the language is delivered in a fun, interactive way, through song and dancewith a WhatsApp group with weekly recordings, videos and images helping everyone keep up , for any reason, someone is unable to attend.The Irish for All class will continue until June and the twinning group hopes to be able to fund an intermediate level follow up next year.The last of the grouprsquos three wellness sessions take place next Friday, March . Thirty therapy sessions will have been delivered by a local therapist Donna Holly from the Wellbeing Company NI, with participants able to choose from a range of hands-on treatments, such as head, back massage or reflexology.Another highlight this year was a presentation by Uacutena Walsh from South Armagh on Celtic Folklore and Legend.Held at the Montalto estate in January, participants were treated to a lively presentation of Celtic myths and legends, which have been passed down through the generations. Uacutena is a passionate local historian.Refreshments were provided to allow the group to enjoy a face-to-face conversation, with the event concluding with a leisurely walk around the Montalto estate nature trails.The twinning group recently held an extraordinary general meeting when a revised constitution was adopted.The group has applied for charitable status and a management team, along with office bearers, will be elected at the annual meeting which takes place on Monday, April .Officials have also confirmed that eight projects have been submitted for funding and over the next  months, with the group hoping to move forward with more cultural, sporting and language events.Tickets for the festival evening at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel on March  are available by making contact via RSCCTG@mail or telephone on  ..prettyPhoto

title: Forest upset the odds in Ardglass
story: CASTLEWELLAN Forest secured their spot in the semi-final stages of the Harry Clarke Cup after they dramatically defeated a favoured Ardglass side on Saturday.Despite trailing by two goals with less than five minutes left on the clock, Forest managed to force extra-time, and then penalties, following a bizarre conclusion to the  minutes that ended with a red card and a fairytale finish.Sean Dornan was the hero between the sticks in the shootout after saving two separate Ardglass efforts while converting his chance from the spot for good measure.To add further to the drama, Dornan was initially outfield for Forest before swapping positions with lsquokeeper Brian McVeigh a minute before the final whistle of extra-time sounded.It was a sunny yet bitterly cold Ardglass venue but that didnrsquot deter things from immediately heating up on the pitch as both teams sought to gain the upper hand early.However, it was the home side who would take the lead within the opening ten minutes when striker Michael Magee struck the ball into the net from close range.This lead would be short-lived as the visitors penned Ardglass back into their own half and soon Castlewellan were rewarded for their relentless attacking.A quickly played pass across the box was met by Forest forward Shane Mooney, who made no mistake with his right footed finish beyond the outstretched arms of Ardglass custodian Mark Armstrong.Chances followed for the visitors, including a Sean Dornan effort that cracked the outside of the post from range and an opportunity for striker Scott Kinley, which quickly diminished after he took too much time on the ball.However, Ardglass refused to be bullied for a prolonged period of time from a side a ision below in the Newcastle League and often launched some dangerous looking counterattacks.One such breakaway ended with Shane Teggart earning his Ardglass side a corner which led to a goalmouth scramble before the ball was headed off the line and away from danger.Ardglass began to find their feet and found more success up front thanks to the probing runs of marksman Magee, who was giving the Castlewellan defence plenty to think about.The Ardglass number nine was unfortunate to see his free-kick effort saved at the second time of asking, but he did give his side the chance to go in front when his nty footwork inside the Forest box resulted in a mistimed tackle and a penalty awarded.Stephen Deegan stepped up a coolly dispatched the spot kick, sending Castlewellan custodian Brian McVeigh the opposite direction in the process.Castlewellan continued to battle with Donagh Steele in the middle of the park having a particularly notable performance as he chased down every loose ball available.Despite their good work, Forest may count themselves fortunate not to go into the break further behind as the usually clinical Magee fluffed his lines from ten yards, missing a golden opportunity for Ardglass.The drama of the first half carried onto the second and in a matter of minutes the referee was forced to make another potentially game changing decision.Once again, the hosts released Magee into the danger area although this time he had Castlewellan captain Aidan Dornan hot on his heels.The move ended with Magee on the ground with his hands in the air appealing for a penalty, however, this time appeals were swtly waved off.The contest quickly turned into a feisty affair as Ardglass looked to overrun their counterparts by sending bodies forward in waves of attacks.Jordan Finnegan saw his snapshot smartly saved by Forest lsquokeeper McVeigh before strike partner Magee saw another one of his efforts tipped wide by the impressive Castlewellan number one.Midway through the half Castlewellan were afforded a seldom opportunity, but Sean Dornan opted to pass when he maybe should have tried his luck at goal instead.Soon after, a punt upfield from the Ardglass defence evaded the heads of the opposition, including lsquokeeper McVeigh, and almost resulted in a rather comedic goal.However, the Castlewellan defence recovered just in the nick of time to avoid any red faces.With  minutes left of the , Ardglass would finally add to their tally after a sumptuous dead ball delivery from Neil Teggart lofted onto the head of team-mate Malachy Crangle, who directed his effort into the net.Castlewellan knew the clock was against them but firmly pushed for a way back into the tie. Rossa McCartan was introduced to the fray off the bench in what proved to be a decisive move from Castlewellan head coach Conall Burns.With a minute of regulation time to go, McCartan danced his way down the line and into the Ardglass box where he was adjudged to be brought down unfairly.Forest striker Mooney converted the penalty to notch his second goal of the match but there was little belief from the surrounding spectators that there would be enough time for another opportunity.In what was seemingly one last throw of the dice, Castlewellan were awarded a free-kick inside their own half and players gathered at the edge of the opposing -yard line waiting for the delivery.However, before the free-kick could be taken, some roughhousing from both sides would end with Ardglass substitute Aidan Watson being shown the red card after he seemingly lost his discipline and kicked out at the opposition.A bizarre series would follow, as the initial free-kick was then brought forward to the -yard line where Watson committed his foul, and from here Castlewellan would take full advantage.Sean Dornan struck his lowly driven effort beneath the jumping Ardglass wall, and goalkeeper Mark Armstrong could only momentarily ert the ball away from goal before the onrushing Callum McCabe would tap-in to draw the sides level.With that, the final whistle of regulation time was blown and extra-time was set to commence.To both sidersquos credit, the intensity of the match remained but neither manufactured any real clear cut chances.Ardglass striker Magee picked up a yellow card but the most notable move of extra-time came from the Castlewellan management, whoopted to swap midfielder Sean Dornan for goalkeeper McVeigh a minute before the penalty shootout.This would prove decisive as Dornan broke Ardglass hearts and saved two penalties, giving his Castlewellan side a memorable victory and place in the last four of the Harry Clarke Cup.Following the dramatic encounter, Dornan reflected on his sidersquos performance.ldquoWe were low on numbers coming down here and we probably werenrsquot as strong as we could be, he said.ldquoBut the credit has to go to the boys, we worked hard and it worked out for us.ldquoWe went - down but we battled hard, got a penalty and a fluky goal.He added: ldquoThe Harry Clarke Cup is blown wide open, Ardglass was probably the favourites and we knocked them out so itrsquos anyones now.Ardglass: M Armstrong, C Kearney, M Crangle, N Teggart, C OrsquoShea, M Rooney , S Deegan, SP Halpin, M Magee, J Finnegan, S Teggart.Subs: S Dorrian, A Watson, J Deegans, A OrsquoShea.Yellow card: M MageeRed card: A WatsonCastlewellan: B McVeigh, C McCabe, C Stratton, C Burns, A Dornan , D Gilmore, S Dornan, D Steele, S Mooney, S Kinley, J Murnin.Subs: C McVeigh, R McCartan..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  March 11%2C 1992
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash Work has begun on the first phase of a major agricultural marketing centre for the Downpatrick area.Diggers moved in this week to begin excavating a ten-acre site for a co-operative project which is being seen as essential to the future of the local farming community.A pound, livestock mart will form the first stage of an ambitious scheme by the Downpatrick Co-Operative Marketing Centre, a limited company which has been set up by more than  local farmers.A covered sale yard and ancillary buildings on the Bonecastle Road site are expected to be finished in time for trading to begin by late July. It will replace the townrsquos previous mart which closed two years ago.However, the mart is part of a much larger project which includes plans for animal processing facilities, a conference centre and extensive retailing outlets.Mr Hugh Linehan, chairman of the co-operative, says it will be the most advanced project of its kind in Northern Ireland and will bring jobs and wealth to the area.ldquoWe see this as the way ahead for local agriculture, Mr Linehan said yesterday.Funding for the mart phase is largely complete. The co-operative has already raised approximately pound, in either shareholdersrsquo capital or in loans. Grant aid from the Food From Britain scheme is also being sought.STRANGFORD ndash A controversial plan to build a new ferry jetty in Strangford has been vetoed by residents.Residents have voted overwhelmingly to reject a pound, scheme by the Department of Environment to build a new mooring jetty away from the main harbour area.A  metre-long steel structure, to be built alongside existing dry-dock facilities, was condemned as a potential eyesore within a designated conservation area.The decision came at a packed public meeting on Wednesday night and it means that the scheme, which could have got underway by October, has now effectively been scrapped.DoE officials had insisted the project would only go ahead subject to local approval.They had taken the view that the jetty would provide a mooring base for the two car ferries, therefore releasing the main quay and much of the harbour for recreational use.The decision to reject the proposal has also thrown into doubt the future of an improvement package for the village which includes the replacement of the existing ferry terminal, environmental improvements and a new traffic system to reduce congestion.Residents were told that money would be made available for the entire project, on condition that the jetty proposal was accepted. With that acceptance not forthcoming, the money is no longer guaranteed and a fresh bid for funding will have to be made.ARDGLASS ndash A Government minister has been challenged to sanction the ldquospending of buttons to end more than  years of misery for the residents of an Ardglass housing estate.Ardglass SDLP councillor Dermot Curran said yesterday he has written to Stormont Minster Jeremy Hanley demanding immediate action to solve the problems associated with Mill River adjacent to the villagersquos Seaview housing estate.ldquoI have submitted a full dossier on the history of long delay in resolving this problem, explained Mr Curran.ldquoSince  I have been asking for the culverting of this river. In  it was indicated it would cost pound, to carry out the work.ldquoIt is disgraceful that the residents of this estate are still being asked to endure this public health hazard on their doorstep. Action is needed before a le is lost.Mr Curran wants the Housing Executive, Department of Agriculture and Department of Environment to share the cost of the scheme.ldquoIt would cost the about pound, each. We have all seen lots of pound,rsquos spent foolishly and disgracefully across Northern Ireland. It is buttons and Mr Hanley, who I have found to be a very fair minister, should consider it as his last good deed before he leaves the island.KILLYLEAGH ndash Educational officials do not anticipate selling the former Killyleagh and Castlewellan high school sites until well into the next financial year.The South Eastern Education and Library Board confirmed this week that despite considerable interest in both complexes there is little prospect of them being sold in the near future.The recession is being blamed for the dficulty, with many developers reluctant to make the large financial commitment necessary to buy either site.However, the Boardrsquos chief architect, Mr Stan Savage, revealed that most interest has been directed at Killyleagh which sits on a prime site overlooking Strangford Lough.He explained that two possible developers are looking closely at the site and have been in negotiation with planning officials over possible developments.ldquoHowever, there has been very limited interest in Castlewellan, said Mr Savage. ldquoIt is the view of the valuation development that it is an unfortunate time to be trying to sell these sort of buildings.ldquoWe do not see either being sold until well into the next financial year, he added.ldquoI am fairly optimistic that we will sell the Killyleagh site but we would be a bit concerned about the future sale of the Castlewellan site.BALLYNAHINCH ndash The GPT site at Ballynahinch has received a Government-backed endorsement of its quality standards.The telecommunications plant has been granted ISO  by the Department of Trade and Industry-approved Lloyds Register Quality Assurance.ldquoThe ISO  is a system developed by the ISO and is an international accreditation. This will assure our customers that the quality systems within GPT can provide and applications needed to offer the most sophisticated business solutions in the network, explained Mr Tony Cobbe, managing director of GPT telecommunications systems group.The award is a timely boost for the Ballynahinch plant which earlier this year laid off  workers. Another GPT manufacturing site at Edge Lane, Liverpool, also attained the standard.NEWCASTLE ndash The Eastern Health Council is to meet a delegation from the Friends of Mourne House early next month to discuss the proposed closure of the Newcastle residential home.The Council has agreed to a request from the local pressure group that its representatives be allowed to speak for the retention of the home at the councilrsquos next meeting in AprilAt Thursdayrsquos monthly meeting members were also told that invitations have been issued to all council members inviting them to visit the home and meet the staff and residents before the April meeting.It is believed a group of council members have already agreed to travel to Newcastle to view the home which is earmarked for closure by the Down and Lisburn unit of management.Down Councilrsquos representative on the council, Mr John Ritchie, encouraged the members to visit the home and see for themselves the excellent work being done in Mourne House.BISHOPSCOURT ndash The thrill of top class motorcycling roars back to le at Bishopscourt this weekend after a gap of  years.The first of seven meetings this season at the former RAF base takes place on Saturday ndash and some of the sportrsquos top names will be there.Among the leading riders who canrsquot wait to test their machines on the . mile circuit are Banbridgersquos Aubrey McCauley, Dave Leach from Katesbridge, Alan Irwin, Ian Gibson and Bangorrsquos Leslie McAllister.Itrsquos exactly  years ago since the airfield hosted its last bike event, but airfield owners David Beattie and John Gfen arenrsquot interested in the past.Theyrsquove got their sights firmly fixed on the future in the hope of bringing world championship grand prix racing to Bishopscourt within the next five years..prettyPhoto

title: I had to end call and go to bunker
story: A BBC cameraman, who beamed pictures from war-torn Kyiv in Ukraine as the Russian army tried to occupy the city, is ing to his home near Crossgar.David McIlveen worked with presenter Clive Myrie last week for the BBCrsquos flagship News at Ten, broadcast live from Kyiv just before the Ukrainian capital came under shellfire.The award-winning picture correspondent ed to London yesterday after spending four weeks in Ukraine.He hopes to get home over the weekend and to be with his we, Emma, and children George and Rose, as well as his parents, George and Irene, who live in Killinchy, and his sister, Karen.As David and his team were leaving Ukraine via Romania, another BBC team were heading to take over their coverage slot at Lviv. The  year-old initially covered the build-up of Russian tanks and soldiers along the border with renowned broadcaster Fergal Keane.He then teamed up with Myrie to record the start of the invasion and subsequent events as the Russian army directed its full military might towards securing Kyiv.David told the Recorder how the consistent shelling of Kyiv at night was having a severe psychological effect, as well as the physical damage on the cityrsquos residents.ldquoThe Russians know exactly what they are doing, with their bombardment of the city at night, he said.ldquoThere is great psychological pressure from listening the sirens go off over and over again at night, not knowing what you are going to face in the morning.He described how a shell hit a building just a block away from him while he was having a ldquoreassuring telephone chat with his we several nights ago.ldquoMy we was understandably getting a bit worried so I went up the top of the hotel where we were staying and where we present the news programme, he said.ldquoThere I was doing a Facetime call with her, trying to reassure her that I was safe when a shell literally hit a building just a block away from where I was.ldquoI just had to end the call and get down to the bunker where we are staying.David said that his days in Kyiv started around am when he and Clive Myrie would would start to move around the city to investigate what had happened to the city overnight.ldquoItrsquos a job where you have to get out and about and find out what has happened and allow people to tell their stories. Itrsquos important for us to be able to witness what is happening in Ukraine, he explained.He said that while they would travel in a mini-van to certain areas of the city, they felt safer approaching some checkpoints by foot due to a potential danger from Ukrainian reservists.ldquoWe felt it was better not to drive up to these checkpoints in a blacked-out minivan as the people manning these literally have had one or two days of training, then be given an AK- and would get a bit nervousa minivan they didnrsquot know pulled up as therersquos so many saboteurs.ldquoWe find it safer to walk around the areas and up to checkpoints as we can been seen from a distance so they can see we are press.He and the rest of a small production crew mdash made smaller as the days went on as non-essential staff were sent home due to the rising safety risks mdash worked long days, covering stories during the day and then preparing for the live news programme.Because of the time dference, the BBC News at Ten started at midnight in Kyiv, ending at am, with the crew having to remove all their equipment to a safe place before being able to rest.He spoke with pride at how he, Myrie and their satellite operators were able to pull off a live one-hour broadcast from a city actively under siege.ldquoI donrsquot think itrsquos very been done before, maybe a live -minute report, but not a whole programme and we are all pleased at being able to pull it off, particularly as so many things could have gone wrong.David won Camera Operator of the Year at last yearrsquos Royal Television Society Awards for the reports he and Myrie did special reports for News at Ten during the pandemic, including a series from the coronavirus wards at the Royal London Hospital.In his  years with the BBC, he has also covered the war in Afghanistan and US Presidential elections.His mother, Irene, spoke of her pride in her sonrsquos work.ldquoItrsquos hard to watch his reports when he is away, particularlyitrsquos a dangerous place like the Ukraine, but itrsquos something that he always wanted to do and Irsquom very proud of him, she saidShe said of the former Killinchy Primary School pupil: ldquoWhen hersquos home, all he wants to be is on the sea in his boat, thatrsquos where hersquos happiest.After resting at home for some time, David expects to be sent back to Ukraine..prettyPhoto

title: Kilcoo legend bids farewell
story: KILCOO bid an emotional farewell to ldquofather figure Mickey Moran after he stepped down from his role as manager on Monday.The  year-old leaves the helm after a defining spell in which he fulfilled the clubrsquos dream of becoming All-Ireland champions.Since his appointment in November , he has led the club to two All-Ireland finals ndash one of which they were defeated in extra-time by Galway champions Corofin ndash as well as winning three county championship titles and two Ulster titles.ldquoWe will always be indebted to Mickey, said club secretary Seamus OrsquoHanlon.ldquoThe first thing is that wersquoll wish him a very long and happy retirement.ldquoOur players had the best relationship you could possibly imagine with Mickey. He was like a father figure to the players in Kilcoo and wersquore sorry to see him go.Moranrsquos assistant managers Conleith Gilligan and Richie Thornton have now been appointed as joint-bosses for the season ahead.The former Magpies manager informed the Kilcoo players of his departure on an emotional evening on Monday, as the club were looking forward to regroup after enjoying a short break following their All-Ireland success.After contacting club chairman Roger Morgan, a meeting was made with the players to allow the man with now legendary status around the village to say his goodbyes.ldquoThe players were all there, said club PRO Michael Kane.ldquoEven the ones that were away were involved through zoom to be part of it. It was an emotional evening.ldquoIt wasnrsquot totally unexpected, we thought it was coming but Mickey decided that he wanted to go out at the top and he thanked the club for everything, he continued.ldquoHe had so much good to say about the players and their attitude and commitment.He added: ldquoTaking the travelling involved and his recent health scares, we totally respect his decision and wersquore forever grateful for what hersquos brought to our club.For Moran, his crowning moment lting the All-Ireland trophy at Croke Park finally brought closure to his search to be on the winning side of a national decider.The Derry-native has had managerial roles at Sligo, Leitrim, Donegal and Mayo which included losing in All-Ireland finals with Mayo in , Slaughtneil in  and , and the previously mentioned  final with Kilcoo.However, he finally held aloft the elusive Andy Merrigan Cup on the steps of the Dublin venue alongside his joint-captains Conor Laverty and Aidan Branagan just three weeks ago.The stepping away from the role may indicate Moranrsquos decision to retire permanently, but it is unknownthat is completely the case at this time.However,Moran does decide to finally call it a day on his managerial career, he will no doubt be remembered throughout the sport as one of the most well respected and memorable coaches in recent history.ldquoWersquore delighted for him that he can go out at the top and he got a guard of honour from our players as he travelled out the lane, said Kane.ldquoHersquoll forever go down as a legend with the respect he has among the people in Kilcoo..prettyPhoto

title: Library turns new page with green credentials
story: DOWNPATRICK Library is going green.Investment to move away from heating the Market Street building with fossil fuel and to install new LED lighting has been welcomed by Rowallane councillor and South Down Alliance election candidate Patrick Brown and Downpatrick councillor Cadogan Enright.To allow the work to be completed, the library has been closed temporarily with the local politicians delighted with the Library Servicersquos commitment to make the Downpatrick building more energy efficient and reduce its carbon footprint.They say the library is expected to reopen next month, once the ious upgrades have been completed.Cllr Brown said while some people were concerned about the closure of the library given the recent reduction of public services in the town, he was delighted to discover that the reason for the temporary closure was to allow new energy efficient measures to be installed.ldquoI am delighted to say that there is no threat to Downpatrickrsquos library service where work is underway to upgrade the entire heating system and fit new LED lighting which should result in a more energy efficient building, he said.Cllr Brown said he and Cllr Enright have been told the work is scheduled to be completed by mid-April, explaining that library members can use nearby libraries and online services in the meantime.ldquoThe Library Service will also be publishing dates for the mobile library visiting the current library site every two weeks, added Cllr Brown.Cllr Enright said that as a ldquocommitted environmentalist he was particularly pleased that the Library Service is moving away from fossil fuels.ldquoThis is why the refurbishment work is taking so long. Downpatrick library is currently heated by an oil-fired system located within the health trust premises next door. Since these premises are now closed permanently, the library must install its own heat source, he explained.ldquoRegular library users will know that the old oil system showed great unreliability in recent years, sometimes resulting in temporary closure.Cllr Enright explained that on the advice of their design consultants, the local library will be avoiding the use of fossil fuels by installing a roof mounted heat recovery system or heat pump, in conjunction with the installation of a new ventilation system.He said that new internal LED light fittings are being installed to improve efficiency and revealed that he has asked the Library Service to install photovoltaic  on its roof.Cllr Enright explained that the  would create free heat and power during daylight hours for the library when paired with a heat pump running on electric power.He added: ldquoEven without this however, the Library Service needs to be praised for being one of the few public bodies in Northern Ireland to turn its back on fossil fuels..prettyPhoto

title: Major extension at Newcastle’s Donard Park set to get approval
story: FORMAL planning approval is expected to be granted today for a major extension to the Donard Park car park in Newcastle.Newry, Mourne and Down Council is investing pound, to formally develop a grass overspill area at the foothills of the Mournes to provide  new spaces.A recommendation to allow the scheme to proceed will be discussed at todayrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee. The extended car park will include  dedicated parking bays for people with mobility issues.As part of the development proposal on land west of the existing car park, a six metre high ball stop fence is being erected and a . metre high paladin fence. There will also be new footpaths, lighting and drainage.None of the statutory agencies have objected to the local authority proposal, but concern was expressed by one resident about the anti-social behaviour of young drivers using the car park.Recommending that the council proposal should be approved, planners said the current overspill car park is considered to be site a ldquosufficient distance from adjacent dwellings to prevent ldquoany unacceptable impacts.Planners say taking into account planning policy, consultee responses, planning history and responses, approval is recommended, also stipulating that prior to any work starting, a final drainage assessment, including a detailed drainage network design and demonstration of how so-called out-of-sewer flooding will be addressed, must be agreed with them.No retained trees will be allowed to be felled or uprooted as part of the work to provide the new parking spaces.Planners have also warned that care will need to be taken during the construction phase to ensure there are no polluting discharges.The contractor appointed to provide the new spaces must submit a so-called final construction method statement and that work cannot begin until approval is in place for the discharge of storm water from the development site has been secured from the Rivers Agency. A final drainage assessment must also be submitted.Protection zones for badger setts in the area must be established, with all trees and hedgerows retained with no external lighting provided until a lighting plan has been submitted to planners and approved.Local politicians are pleased that the main car park in Newcastle is to be extended which will make a dference during the busy holiday periods.They say there will be aon the local authorityrsquos signicant investment to provide additional parking for visitors and residents in the resort.Previously, the overflow area for cars at the rear of Donard Park has been described as ldquounsightly and particularly dficult to manage in wet weather, with the extension providing a modern parking facility to meet the needs of a range of drivers.Itrsquos also understood that the overspill car park may include a number of charging points for electric vehicles..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle ‘needs and deserves’ new centre
story: A DETAILED report on building a new multi-million pound leisure centre in Newcastle is expected to be completed shortly.Newry, Mourne and Down Council officials are working with consultants to develop an outline business case which is designed to pave the way for the eagerly-awaited new complex, with councillors expected to be provided with a copy of the report within the next few weeks.The rear of the existing Newcastle Centre and the outdoor Tropicana swimming pool are to be demolished to make way for the new town centre leisure complex, with formal planning approval to send in the bulldozers expected to be rubber-stamped at todayrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Planning Committee.Once the demolition work has been completed, the rear of the Newcastle Centre will be restored to its original design, with two sash windows reinstated to match those of the original building.In addition, alterations will be carried out to the boundary wall, alongside the removal of a reinforced concrete fence  and metal gates. The gates will be replaced with a perforated double metal gate.Planners say the removal of the ldquobulky rear extension to the existing listed building can only be seen as a betterment to its integrity and intrinsic character ldquo.In addition, they say the demolition proposal does not ldquooffend the essential character of the building with its setting retained and its features of special interest remaining intact and unimpaired.Planners have also stipulated that any proposed demolition work proposed within one metre of the Newcastle Centre shall be carried out by hand and that no power tools must be used to ensure no damage to the existing building.The proposed new leisure complex will feature an indoor leisure pool which includes three  metre swimming lanes and a dedicated heated play pool for children.Itrsquos also understood that the eagerly-awaited new leisure facility will also feature an ultra-modern gymnasium and once demolition work has been completed, the new complex will be bolted on to the side of the existing centre.Redeveloping the existing Newcastle Centre has been ruled out due to the scale of the costs involved and itrsquos understood that the planned new-build will be larger than the current centre which enjoys protected status, posing major problems for the council in transforming it into an energy efficient facility which meets current building regulations and standards.Late last year, it was revealed that an economist and team of expert consultants would be appointed to design the new leisure facility, with Newry, Mourne and Down Council adding an additional pound, to its capital programme to help deliver the new complex.The planned investment at the current Newcastle Centre housed in the Annesley Buildings is also a key plank of the local authorityrsquos capital investment programme.Mournes councillor, Laura Devlin, said it was well known that Newcastle ldquoneeds and deserves a fit-for-purpose leisure centre.She said while the local authority has faced many hurdles over recent years in delivering a new leisure complex, all Mournes councillors understand there are no longer any available sites within the town which are of a suitable size to build what is needed.But Cllr Devlin said this could not be used as an excuse, highlighting the need to deliver for the people of town and visitors.ldquoThe council is proceeding with plans for a replacement centre on the current Newcastle Centre site, she continued. ldquoFrom the outset of this process I have said that this must include a pool and that remains my position.ldquoI appreciate there are swimming pools within the district butwe are serious about tourism we need to look at a rainy day offering in Newcastle and I believe that a pool would tick that box, as well as providing a superb facility for our local community.Cllr Devlin said she looks forward to forward to seeing the outline business case and the eagerly-awaited project progressing at long last.Detailed work has already been carried out at the town centre site, including geotechnical surveys which examined ground conditions to provide architects and designers with key information ahead of construction work getting underway.While no detailed timescales are in place, politicians hope that major progress to deliver the project can now be made, with planning permission and all other associated approvals secured in a timely fashion.Two sites were previously identied for the new centre, with sports pitches at Donard Park the preferred option. However, councillors subsequently switched attention to the former St Maryrsquos Girlsrsquo Primary School site at nearby Shanslieve Drive but lost out in a bidding war to supermarket giant Lidl.Local politicians say they are keen to see progress on the new leisure complex and are pleased that it will now include an indoor pool as residents have been looking for a modern leisure complex for over two decades..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle man Jack to embark on sky jump in memory of aunt
story: A NEWCASTLE man will jump out of a plane from , feet to raise money for a childrenrsquos cancer charity.Jack Welshhas decided to take the plunge in memory of his aunt Joanne, who sadly passed away in .Going one step further in his fundraising efforts, the full-time barber is also opting to completely shave his head in a bid to raise even more money for his chosen charity, Cancer Fund for Children.ldquoI have been wanting to do something like this for a while so I thought I would just go for it, said Jack.ldquoMy aunty is the main inspiration behind the jump and I feel like the chosen charity is definitely a worthwhile one.ldquoMy family couldnrsquot be any more supportive, they are behind me all the way so that helps spur me on as the big day approaches.Jack will take to the skies on Saturday, March , and will also shave his head on the same day. Despite partaking in the jump with a group of  other people, the fitness enthusiast willbe the only inidual to get rid of their locks as well.ldquoAs a barber I tend to keep my hair in order, but at the end of the day itrsquos all for a good cause and I will throw on a hatneeds be, he joked.ldquoThere are more important things in le, sothis can contribute to raising even more money, Irsquom all for it.Usually skyes take place from , feet but Jack searched online to see just how big he could go.ldquoI found Skye Wild Geese based in Belfast, who offer the opportunity to jump from , feet which is the biggest throughout the UK and Ireland, said Jack.ldquoI am a mixture of nervous and excited but I am without doubt looking forward to it.Jack has reached over half of his initial pound target, although he says he simply just wants to raise ldquoas much as possible before the deadline.To donate to Jackrsquos fundraising efforts, visit https:www.facebook donate    or call into Thee Menrsquos Rooms in Newcastle and Downpatrick collection boxes are available..prettyPhoto

title: Once in a lifetime opportunity for fishery investment
story: A WARNING has been issued that political stalemate must not be allowed to derail a ldquoonce in a letime opportunity to invest in the future of Ardglass harbour.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and local councillor Dermot Curran said it is vital that the Fishing and Seafood Development Programme is implemented in full to provide support for the local port and neighbouring coastal communities in Kilkeel and Portavogie.The report was produced following a strategic review of the opportunities for developing the sea fishing and seafood sectors across the province, including the potential role of new public investment in infrastructure.Investment in the region of poundm is needed in Ardglass, according to the report, which focused on recommendations in relation to capital investment at the local ports, alongside the challenges and opportunities for the wider industry that could be addressed through a future fisheries financial support scheme.Mr McGrath said the report offers the fisheries sector a once in a letime opportunity for investment, development and job sustainability.ldquoWhat we are talking about is a multi-million-pound development and Cllr Curran and I have been working with the Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs [DAERA] and the fishing industry in Ardglass see this programme progress, he said.ldquoThis is a unique opportunity for the local fishing industry must be grasped and not blocked because the DUP has decided to run a coach and horses through the Northern Ireland Executive and any decision-making process.Mr McGrath says the Co Down fishing industry has been ldquodecimated as a result of Brexit and been short changed by the British government in only receiving poundm of the poundm-a-year worth of additional quota which it was due.He remarked: ldquoThe industry cannot be sold out by the NI Executive because of rows over the Protocol, which was a direct consequence of Brexit. We are interested in solutions and putting people first and the Fishing and Seafood Development programme is one solution we must deliver on.ldquoI hope voters will remember issues such as this in May as they will be the people who elect a new Executive.Cllr Curran said the fishing and fish processing industries were an essential part of le in Ardglass and the local economy.ldquoThese industries must be protected and enhanced and this is all achievable, he declared.ldquoIt is welcome news that approval has been given for the programmersquos strategic outline case which allows DAERA to procure consultants to take forward detailed environmental and technical studies.ldquoHowever, this approval only allows DAERA to incur expenditure on work required to inform the later outline business cases upon which any later decisions to proceed with infrastructure development, such as the deepening of Ardglass harbour will be based.Cllr Curran said he hoped that the absence of the NI Executive and the uncertainty of its future does not obstruct the progress of the ldquovital fishing programme which offers so much potential for Ardglass and other local ports..prettyPhoto

title: Regional rates frozen for business owners
story: BUSINESSES and ratepayers have received some good news with confirmation that the regional rate has been frozen for another year.The decision by Stormont finance minister Conor Murphy is part of a poundm province-wide rates support package for the new financial year.He has also confirmed that the small business rate relief scheme benefiting thousands of business premises will also continue, explaining the message from businesses is that the rates holiday was a vital leline for them during the pandemic.The finance minister said the poundm rates support package to support the recovery will provide all businesses with a one month rates holiday with the exception of utilities and larger food stores while retail, hospitality, tourism, leisure, childcare, newspapers and airports will receive a three months rates holiday.Mr Murphy said businesses in the hardest hit sectors had paid no rates since March  and will now pay no rates until July.He said freezing the regional rate is intended to help with the rising costs being faced by families and businesses alike, with the extension of the small business rate relief scheme resulting in businesses automatically receiving a reduction of between % and % on their rates.The finance minister added: ldquoSmall businesses are at the core of our local economy and have a vital role in contributing to employment opportunities.ldquoI am glad to announce the continuation of the small business rate relief scheme which currently supports almost , business premises. The extension of the scheme sends a strong message of the important contribution of the small business sector.Last month, Newry, Mourne and Down Council imposed a .% rates rise to finance its poundm budget, with the hike the second lowest increase of any of the provincersquos  local authorities.Rates are made up of two parts mdash the regional rate and the district rate.The regional rate is set by Stormont and, along with the block grant from the Treasury, pays for the likes of schools, health and roads. The district rate is set by local councils and pays for services that the council is responsible for, such as refuse collection, leisure provision and street cleaning.While councils have the power to set dferent rates increases for households and businesses, this year they have chosen to instead set one percentage increase for both.Domestic and non-domestic rates are calculated by multiplying the rateable valuation of homes and businesses by the combined district and regional rate.Domestic and non-domestic rates are set in terms of the number of pence in each pound of the value of your home business. For instance, in the Newry, Mourne and Down council area, the domestic rate for the   financial year is . pence, while the non-domestic rate will be . pence.Key factors that councils have to take into account when setting their district rate, including cost of living, inflation, the councilrsquos own financial reserves and other income, and the wider economic outlook.Last year, several councils chose to freeze their rates due to the impact of the pandemic, dipping into their reserves to absorb the loss of income. Others chose to raise their rates slightly, however this has meant playing a degree of catch-up this year, when all councils have opted to hike their rates.As a result of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos rates increase, local communities are set to share a poundm funding boost in the new financial year.The organisation said it recognises that communities have been hit hard over the past number of years, outlining plans for poundm of financial assistance grants for community and voluntary organisations.In addition, the local authority will also manage the establishment of the Peace Plus Partnership as well as the submission and delivery of the Peace Plus Local Authority Action Plan worth around poundm.The action plan will provide priority projects on a cross-community basis, resulting in shared and inclusive local services, facilities and spaces and make a ldquosignicant and lasting contribution to peace and reconciliation for the whole community.In addition, pound.m will be invested on a new fleet of over  modern and more efficient vehicles across a range of services including refuse collection, district cleansing and parks and grounds maintenance with the new vehicles expected to arrive before the end of this year..prettyPhoto

title: Sense have been at  the core of Páuric’s  development and they have done a lot for us
story: A CASTLEWELLAN woman braved the winds and rain last month to walk  miles in aid of the disability charity, Sense.Janine Laverty was inspired to take on Sensersquos Run For challenge to give back to the charity which supports her disabled son.So far Janine has raised an amazing total of over pound, through her challenge, but she is aiming to raise pound, in total.Participants challenged themselves to run or walk a distance of their choosing over the month of February.Janine finished her -mile target on February , completing her challenge with a seaside walk.She undertook the walk to support the charity which has meant so much to her family since her youngest son Paacuteuric, , was born premature and has cerebral palsy, developmental delay and dficulties with his vision.Family and friends have rallied around Janine , joining her on walks and generously donating to Sense.Sense services in Northern Ireland have supported Paacuteuric since he was an infant, providing key interventions such as play therapy, music therapy and guide dog days which boosted his development.Janine also credits Sense with providing some of her most precious family memories support from the charity allowed her to take both her sons swimming at the same time, and the family have attended fun-filled Sense days out to places including Ark Open Farm, Armagh Planetarium and Jungle Northern Ireland.Janine explained: ldquoSense Northern Ireland have been at the core of Paacuteuricrsquos development and they have done an awful lot for us. Paacuteuric has exceeded all of our expectations and now enjoys going to a mainstream pre-school ndash all the early interventions really paid off.ldquoIrsquove wanted to be able to give back to Sense for a long time, but le has been so busy with all of Paacuteuricrsquos appointments. With both my boys now in school I finally have time to get out and do something to support Sense.ldquoItrsquos fantastic that so many people have supported my challenge and learnt about Paacuteuric. I hope that by sharing our story more parents who have children with additional needs will know about the support Sense can provide them.Sense chief executive Richard Kramer said: ldquoWe are very grateful that Janine has chosen to support Sense by taking on this challenge. Thanks to Janinersquos fundraising, Sense will be able to support more people in Northern Ireland who have complex disabilities to communicate and experience the world.To sponsor Janine, visit https:runfor.sense.org.uk fundraising sense-our-turn-to-support-you..prettyPhoto

title: St Patrick’s Grammar School head girl celebrates after winning singing show
story: EVA Rowan, the head girl of St Patrickrsquos Grammar School in Downpatrick, has been crowned BBC School Soloist of the Year .The  year-old won the coveted title last Sunday as it was announced on BBC One Northern Ireland on Sunday.She was in the schoolrsquos senior secondary school section along with Cara Keaveney from Assumption Grammar in Ballynahinch, Sarah Hoben from Our Ladyrsquos Grammar School in Newry and Amy Ford from Dunclug Academy in Ballymena.The Annacloy girl was with her parents, Micheal and Lucille, when compere Conor Phillips announced she had won.Hundreds of entries were submitted to the BBC for each age group ndash primary, junior secondary and senior secondary mdash in a competition that celebrates the communal aspect of choral singing.After weeks of competing through heats broadcast on BBC Radio Ulster and BBC Sounds, she made it through to the final in the BBCrsquos Blackstaff Studios in Belfast.The three judges mdash Sheelagh Greer, Alan Leech and Sarah Richmond mdash were very impressed with Evarsquos performances of No One Is Alone and Taylor The Latte Boy, awarding her the title and a trophy.When asked by the judges how she felt winning the entire competition, Eva said: ldquoMy heart is going a million miles an hour and it isnrsquot even the caffeine in a reference to her Taylor The Latte Boy song.All the finalists were asked to choose a new piece for the final, and Eva chose a piece in tribute to Stephen Sondheim, who sadly passed away last November. Eva felt that No One Is Alone from Into the Woods embodied an important message to all who may be struggling at this time.Eva and her family had to keep the news of her win to themselves until the final wastelevised last weekend.ldquoThe hardest thing to do was have to sit on this for over a week, she said. ldquoIt was a total dream to be on a stage like this, and the realisation that this was actually happening was a dream come true. It was so positively, emotionally overwhelming.Eva, who performs with St Patrickrsquos Choral Society in Downpatrick, had the greatest respect for the talents of her fellow competitors.She joined St Patrickrsquos two years ago to study for A Levels in Music, Drama and English and has always been vocal in her appreciation of how the school has supported her.ldquoThroughout my entire time in school I have always felt supported, and each day has opened new opportunities.Eva paid tribute to her accompanist, Darren Day, who ldquomade the process so much easier and his ability to make her feel at ease.She was also very grateful to the BBC for the opportunity to work with a live string quartet, performed so beautully by the Aria Quartet, as the sound that was created really brought to le her final song.Eva also paid tribute to her singing tutors, Courtney Burns and Adam Darcy, and her teacher, Mrs Celeste McEvoy, who entered her submission to the BBC and was with her at every stage of the competition.Evarsquos singing ability has been nurtured from a tender age. As a very young member of the choir at Holy Family Church in Teconnaught, she listened to family members singing in the choir and was encouraged and supported by singer and guitarist Laura Larkin.As a nine year-old, Eva was in the St Patrickrsquos Choral Societyrsquos production of The Sound of Music in which her brother Ciaran sang The Lonely Goatherd. Her love for musical theatre was born and she later took on ious lead roles.She has a dream of continuing on with musical theatre work after studying it at university and has her eyes set on top roles.ldquoMy favourite roles would be Angelica in Hamilton, Vivian in Legally Blonde and Mrs Lovett in Sweeney Todd, she said. ldquoThese roles were all strong, independent women.Eva has struck up a great working partnership with fellow St Patrickrsquos students Lucien Coole and Edward Gilmore in their busking three-piece, The Thing Is.They have recently been employed at the Downpatrick Artisan Market, and on St Patrickrsquos Day will be providing entertainment in Downpatrick.Eva will also be entertaining the audience at the St Patrickrsquos Centre tonight during Gerry Kellyrsquos interview with Patrick Kielty. She will be singing No One Is Alone. Gerry, Patrick and Eva are all alumni of St Patrickrsquos High School.The BBC School Soloist of the Year  final is available to watch on the BBC iPlayer..prettyPhoto

title: Stunning floats set to bring splash of colour to parade
story: NEXT weekrsquos St Patrickrsquos Day parade in Downpatrick will feature a number of stunning floats based around Irish mythology.Downpatrick Town Committee and Down Community Arts have been busy working on five superbly crafted floats which are set to make a major impact next Thursday and turn heads as the festival parade makes its way through the town.With funding provided by Newry, Mourne and Down Council and the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, hours of painstaking work will be revealed next week.Philip Campbell, from Down Community Arts and a member of Downpatrick Town Committee, is pleased with the spectacular new floats and hopes that the collaboration which made them possible, will continue for the next few years to create even more stunning pieces of work.Children from a number of Downpatrick primary schools are also involved in the project and itrsquos expected that around  of them dressed in costume will accompany the five floats.This week, the children have been taking part in workshops to help complete the floats and prepare for Thursdayrsquos parade.ldquoA lot of work has gone into preparing for the festival parade and we are delighted with all the support that we have received, said Philip.ldquoThe financial support from the local council and the Arts Council has been major benefit and we have been able to source all the materials that we need locally which has helped support local businesses.Philip said it has been good to involve local primary school children in the project and has thanked them and their teachers for taking part.Work has been continuing to build the floats in the Down Arts Centre with one of the stunning new creations being made in Lurgan, but will be transported to Downpatrick for the big day.ldquoWe have been working on the project since January  with the help of local artist Kieron Back and Rab Galbraith and John Wilson from the Town Committee have played key roles in getting us to where we are today, Philip continued.ldquoThe theme of the floats is Irish mythology and they include the Brown Bull of Ulster, Legananny Dolmen and Manannaacuten mac Lir. The float being built in Lurgan features the Children of Lir.Philip said all those involved with the Downpatrick parade are conscious that the last event was held in .ldquoWe are making the most of the opportunity to participate in the first major outdoor event staged in the district since the coronavirus pandemic, he said.ldquoOur aim is to build on the work we have done this year and secure additional funding over the next two years so that by  we could have up to  floats in the St Patrickrsquos Day parade.Philip said Downpatrick Town Committee is keen to maximise the opportunities the town has and also make statement that it has the biggest March  cross-community festival parade..prettyPhoto

title: There is no food%2Cno water%2Cno gas and the city outskirts  are surrounded by landmines
story: A UKRAINIAN woman is desperate for help in securing visas and safe passage to bring her mother, brother and sister-in-law to County Down.Iryna Johnston and her husband Jonathan are calling on people to sign a petition calling on the Government to waive visa requirements for Ukrainian refugees coming to the UK.After days of waiting on word from her family as they shelter in bombed city of Mariupol, the local couple were relieved that she received message only saying ldquoWe are alive on WhatsApp yesterday morning.The couple do not where her family members are staying in the encircled city in the Donetsk Oblast area or how long they will be safe.ldquoThere is no food, no water, no gas and the city outskirts are surrounded by landmines and itrsquos snowing there, said Mrs Johnston.Refugees escaping from Mariupol were targeted just days ago when an agreed safe corridor was disrupted by Russian shelling.The city sits in a strategic location, splitting Russian forces on the annexed Crimean Peninsula from separatist troops in eastern Ukraine.Mrs Johnstonrsquos mother, Tamara, is in her early seventies and is believed to be with her son, Alexander, and his we, Olga, who live nearby.Mr Johnston said that he and his we are desperate that they leave Mariupol and get to safety.ldquoWe would take her mother and family, even cousins and other in-lawsthey could get visas, he told the Recorder.ldquoEventhey could get a visa to Dublin, I would happily rent a place for them just over the border near Newry, then they would only be about  minutes away.He said that another possible route to safety may be for his wersquos family to go to St Petersburg where his sister-in-law still has a flat.ldquoWe just want them to be safe. Politically the situation is much more complicated in the eastern part of Ukraine. People in the eastern part of the country are very Russian. But % of the people in the Ukraine donrsquot care about politics and just what a happy, peaceful le.Mr Johnston described the now impractical steps his relatives which have to taken in order to get a visa.ldquoThey would normally have to travel  hours on an overnight train from Mariupol to Kyiv to get a visa granted for travel. In the current situation that is just not possible, he said.ldquoThe only way for people to get out is through the only UK embassy open in Lviv and how are people are meant top get there when they canrsquot leave their own towns without the risk of being bombed Mr Johnston added that he and his we and their children, Liza and Jamie, were frustrated that their family members could be just one plane flight away from safetythey could get the necessary visa, orthat could be waived in the urgent circumstances.He said: ldquoWe are worried aboutthe possibility of Alexander being coned to fight and we are getting reports that landmines have been set around the city.ldquoWhile we are all worried, Iryna has been remarkable throughout all of this and has been really strong but we feel that there is very little we can do.Mr Johnston said that they were in despair of the UKrsquos stance in welcoming Ukrainian refugees but still making them apply for visas.ldquoThe south of Ireland opened up to refugees visa-free which is great but that means we still couldnrsquot bring them to our home as they would be in UK territory.He and his family visited Mariupol for six weeks last summer as it has already proved dficult for his mother-in-law to get a visa to travel to them.ldquoMariupol is such a beautul city. They had spent so much money on the city and now itrsquos ruined.The couple met in Ukraine while Mr Johnston, a flutist, was performing in cruise ships and his we was a concert pianist.To sign the petition to waive visa requirements for Ukrainian refugees coming into the UK visit https:petition.parliament.uk petitions ..prettyPhoto

title: wearing masks in school is of no benefit to children but rather causes harm
story: Energy crisis: NI Protocol could limit VAT relief to tackle fuel costs, says TUV leader   PSNI issue update on suspected abduction of young maleNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisUkraineSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes  Gardense-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionWearing masks in school is of no benefit to children but rather causes harmA letter from Hugh McCarthy:By LettersThursday, rd March , : amUpdated Thursday, rd March , : am  "       "  A school pupil’s capacity to express feelings is affected by being masked. Non-verbal communication with teachers is lostWhy are Northern Ireland school children still wearing masks Now that the English, Welsh and Scottish governments have dropped the requirement for schoolchildren to wear masks and it is optional in the Irish Republic, why are our children still strongly recommended to wear them in school This is plainly ridiculous.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The overwhelming body of scientic evidence shows that children are almost totally unaffected by the virus, whilst the evidence for the efficacy of masks has always been weak .What is indisputable is that wearing masks cause harm. Teaching, and hence learning, relies on communication, the essential verbal and non-verbal communication between child and teacher cannot take place behind a mask. All those non-verbal cues which teachers use to gauge understanding are being lost.A child’s capacity to express feelings and emotions is being affected by being masked. Some children cannot make eye contact and can’t sleep, clear signs of psychological distress and of course, impacting on their capacity to learn. Referrals to schools’ counselling services have rocketed.How can it be healthy for a child to wear a mask six or seven hours per day How can we justy a measure which has no benefit to children and accept the damage to their education, mental health and social development It is long past the time to end this abuse of our children.Hugh McCarthy, , Newtownabbey——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: sports direct reveals uks loved sports teams including arsenal chelsea
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe sports retailer analysed teams associated with leagues across eight sports from up and down the country and crafted a list based on a number of critical factors.The researchers looked at everything from the teams brand sentiment on social media to its number of online searches.The ranking was also constructed by looking at online mentions, social following and fan engagement.Sports Direct store. Credit: PA "Sports Teams are the bread and butter of the sporting world," the sportswear brand said.It added: "They matter immensely to fans and to iniduals themselves, but which ones are the most loved across the UK "                                                                                                              : Six Nations referees  - meet the refs assigned to every game: Winter Olympics: Triumphant curling teams land in Scotland                                                                                                              Sports Direct has rounded up the UKs most popular sports and its definitely an interesting mix.Most Loved Sports. Credit: Sports Direct Unsurprisingly, Football tops the list with an average of ,, loves on social media, the retailer has confirmed.Coming in second and third is Rugby League and Union respectively and rounding up the ranking is Athletics.FootballRugby LeagueRugby UnionIce HockeyCricketNetballRowingAthleticsDid you know that you can shop by sport on the Sports Direct websiteIf youre looking for gear and equipment to try out a new sport, youll find all the kits you could possibly need in the ious sports categories on its website. Whether youre a running rookie or youre nuts about the NFL, Sports Direct can keep you right. .removeShop the collection via the Sports Direct website.Top  sports in the UK. Credit: Sports Direct Sports Direct has crafted its top  list and we arent surprised to see Football dominate the top  spots of the most popular sports teams in the UK. However, youll find other sports teams in the ranking this year with beloved Ice Hockey, Rugby Union, Netball and Athletics making the top  list. You can see the full breakdown of the sports team rankings via the Sports Direct website which includes fan favourites like Cricket and Rowing too.Arsenal - FootballLiverpool- FootballCha - FootballMan City - FootballWest Ham - FootballCardf Devils - Ice HockeyGloucester - Rugby UnionShaftesbury Barnett Harriers - AthleticsGuildford Flames - Ice HockeyHarlequins - Rugby UnionNorthampton Saints - Rugby UnionSaracens - Rugby UnionTeam Bath Netball - NetballLeicester Tigers - Rugby UnionWoodford Green and Essex Ladies - AthleticsFootball fans can shop for their teams kits and wear strips from some of the countrys biggest teams including Manchester United, Newcastle United, Tottenham Hotspur and more.Meanwhile, Rugby Union fans can sports strips from Wales, England and Scotland by picking one up from the Sports Direct website.
